urn:contentItem:3Y2X-K5T0-009B-G1S3-00000-00Investors Buy in the Bond Pits and at the Big Board; FreeMarkets Cashes in on IPO Frenzy; LVMH Shows Why Luxury Has Never Looked so Good1999-12-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:47ZLexisNexisCNN MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR 18:30 pm ETBusinessSHOW99121000V19Investors Buy in the Bond Pits and at the Big Board; FreeMarkets Cashes in on IPO Frenzy; LVMH Shows Why Luxury Has Never Looked so GoodStuart Varney, Greg Clarkin, Kelli Arena, Bruce Francis, Steve Young, Fred Katayama, Jennifer Auther, Allan Dodds Frank, Peter Viles

On Wall Street today, the week ended with yet another record session for the Nasdaq composite and solid gains for the Dow, as investors celebrated the absence of inflation, another round of stellar stock debuts and lower oil prices. Today, business-to- business online auctioneer FreeMarkets went public at $48 a share, hit a high of $293 and closed at $280 for a gain of 483 percent, a stunning debut just a day after VA Linux shattered all previous IPO records. LVMH, the European firm whose four initials are synonymous with luxury, is the French empire behind world-class brands like Moet Chandon, Louis Vuitton and Christian Dior, and it is run by a Frenchman known as one of Europe's most ruthless dealmakers.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

STUART VARNEY, CNN ANCHOR: Tonight, buying in the bond pits and at the big board. Investors cheer the latest news on inflation and a big drop in oil prices.

The IPO frenzy lives on. FreeMarkets, the dot-com company generating a ton of interest but absolutely no profits.

And never has luxury looked so good. Tonight, "The Bottom Line" on LHMH, the fashion powerhouse built with high-priced brands and bolstered by star power.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ELTON JOHN, SINGER: Louis Vuitton was just a luggage label, all right? And now it does everything. It's one of the hippest labels around.

GWYNETH PALTROW, ACTRESS: I think it will continue as long as the stock market is bullish.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ANNOUNCER: This is THE MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR. Reporting tonight from New York, Stuart Varney.

VARNEY: Good evening, everyone, and welcome to MONEYLINE. Tonight, it is Willow who is on assignment.

As for Wall Street, the week ended with yet another record session for the Nasdaq composite. Investors celebrated the absence of inflation and another round of stellar stock debuts. The buying really picked up in the final hour of trading.

Greg Clarkin has more in today's "STREET SWEEP."

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GREG CLARKIN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): It was a vote of confidence for the workings of the so-called "new economy." FreeMarkets is a Web site that lets companies bid on everything from raw materials to commodities to parts -- an eBay for businesses. And today investors wildly bid up the company's shares, more than 480 percent, in its Wall Street debut.

ERIC YUPIN, BANKBOSTON ROBERTSON STEPHENS: That market and that space in particular has much more opportunity for this kind of company to capture higher margins and achieve greater transaction volumes and greater transaction fees. Hence bigger company, more margin potential here.

CLARKIN: FreeMarkets wasn't the only stock with a white-hot debut. EBenx soared 124 percent on its first day of trading. ESpeed, an electronic communication network spun off from the Wall Street firm Cantor Fitzgerald, shot up 99 percent. And El Sitio, a Spanish and Portuguese language Web site, zoomed 108 percent.

The buying binge didn't stop at the newcomers. The Nasdaq composite added 26 points to 3620, its 51st record close of the year.

Even without the help of tech perennials IBM and Intel, the blue chips managed to climb within 101 points of their August record. The Dow Jones industrials gained 89 points to close at 11,224.

But some market watchers caution the rally in technology shares is overdone.

PETER CARDILLO, WESTFALIA INVESTMENTS: If you look at some of these technology stocks, especially the Internet technology stocks, they have excessive valuations at this time. And I believe that in the first quarter of the new year, this market is headed for some rough times. And I -- we could see a 10 to 15 percent correction in the Nasdaq, and a 10 percent in the Dow.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CLARKIN: And even one more IPO to keep an eye on out for, insurance and money management giant John Hancock Financial Services. The company said it will offer 102 million shares to the public, each priced at $15 to $25. John Hancock expects to raise nearly $2 billion from this IPO -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Greg Clarkin reporting. Thank you, Greg.

Now the stocks have rallied. It really picked up momentum after a big plunge in crude oil prices. The U.N. Security Council voted to renew Iraq's oil-for-food deal for another six months. That means Iraq can, if it chooses, start exporting oil as early as next week. Light sweet crude dropped 92 cents to $25.53 a barrel, bouncing back a bit from the lows of the session.

The sharp drop in oil prices boosted the inflation-wary bond market. Traders also liked that weaker-than-expected report on wholesale prices. The Treasury's 30-year issue moved up 22 ticks, and that put the yield back down to 6.16 percent. And that is, by the way, the lowest level in some three weeks.

Holding down long-term interest rates, a steady drumbeat of weaker-than-expected news on inflation. Today, it was the producer price index, edging up just two-tenths of one percent in November. And excluding a big jump in food and energy costs, the "core rate," as it's called, the core rate of wholesale inflation would not have budged at all, as Kelli Arena reports.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KELLI ARENA, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Most Wall Street economists say investors should rest easy. Inflation has yet to rear its ugly head.

GARY THAYER, A.G. EDWARDS: Things are still very benign outside of oil. The strong dollar is keeping most other prices contained. As a matter of fact, if you look at the PPI numbers this year, we've had weakness in apparel and food, in capital goods prices.

ARENA: But oil, always a wild card, is rising. The energy component accounted for much of the November rise in wholesale prices, up 1.4 percent, driven largely by a spike in heating oil and residential electric power. But so far, economists do not view it as a threat.

KEVIN LOGAN, DRESDNER KLEINWORT BENSON: It's still very, very modest. In the past year, prices fell rather sharply. And now that we're seeing some recovery in the global economy, these prices are also beginning to recover. But it's not a threat to inflation.

ARENA: It is a threat to the administration, however. Energy Secretary Bill Richardson yesterday said the U.S. is willing to do whatever it takes to protect consumers.

Looking back over the past 12 months, wholesale prices are up 3.1 percent.

(on camera): Economists say that should help reassure Federal Reserve policy makers who meet on December 21st to decide the future course of interest rates.

Kelli Arena, CNN financial news, Washington.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VARNEY: Chief economist at Merrill Lynch, Bruce Steinberg, thought the Fed's November rate hike would be its last for quite a while. A week ago, though, he changed his mind, saying the strength of the economy could indeed force the Fed to raise rates in the near future. And he joins me now.

Bruce, welcome to the program.

BRUCE STEINBERG, MERRILL LYNCH: Thank you, Stuart.

You think we're in an old-fashioned boom, don't you? And you think it's going to continue to next year.

STEINBERG: It's not an old-fashioned boom, it's a new economy boom. Our economy is just going great. But despite the strong growth that we're having, there's just no inflation pressure that's observable at all. And I think we can keep on going for quite some time.

VARNEY: But if there's no inflation pressure visible, why should the Fed raise rates?

STEINBERG: What the Fed is chiefly worried about is that we're about to run out of people. And the unemployment rate is very low. The economy is quite strong, and that's what it's really reacting to. It's not reacting to the actuality of inflation, of which there isn't any, it's worried somehow that down the road we might get some. I don't think they're right on that, but that's what they are reacting to. And that's why I think that they'll probably have to tighten policy again.

VARNEY: Your bet is then the Fed does raise rates early in the year, fairly early on?

STEINBERG: Probably in February. If not, then in March.

VARNEY: Now if we've got such a robust economy, what does that do for corporate profits next year, because that really is the baseline for the stock market's performance?

STEINBERG: I think corporate profits are going to be great next year, another year of double digit earnings growth for the S&P 500. This year, earnings are probably going to end up going up 15 percent or so, and I think next year they'll be up almost as strongly.

VARNEY: Boy, you say we're in a new economy. How much longer can we go on like this? I mean, nine years of growth, 200,000 new jobs every month, no inflation, et cetera, et cetera. Can you put a time frame on when we're going to run out of steam?

STEINBERG: You know, we haven't repealed the business cycle. There will be a downturn someday. But frankly it's just not on the horizon. We don't how long this can last. We are in uncharted territory. It makes it hard to analyze, kind of exciting to look at. But it could go on for several more years at least.

VARNEY: What do you think could upset everything? Is there something you could imagine on the horizon out there?

STEINBERG: The biggest risk in terms of the near term is that the Fed thinks the party is just getting a little too frenetic and it decides to take away the punch bowl, so to speak, by continuing to tighten policy in 2000. And if it tightens more than a couple of times, that will have a chilling effect on the economy by late next year.

VARNEY: Have you ever seen anything like this before?

STEINBERG: No one has anything like this before.

VARNEY: That for real? Nobody has seen anything…

STEINBERG: No.

VARNEY: This is unique?

STEINBERG: This is unique, yes.

VARNEY: We'll leave it at that. Bruce Steinberg, Merrill Lynch, thanks very much.

STEINBERG: OK.

VARNEY: Now let's take a quick look at some of the other stories that we're working on for MONEYLINE tonight. And we begin with Bruce Francis.

BRUCE FRANCIS, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Thanks, Stuart.

IBM has been a big bust late this week, and Xerox is putting out some news that it won't want to copy. I'll have the story behind the numbers for these two tech giants.

STEVE YOUNG, CNN CORRESPONDENT: I'm Steve Young.

FreeMarkets.com had a flashy IPO today because it's got a lock on the business-to-business Internet auction market. But as I'll explain, patent lawyers warn it could face stiff competition from other public companies.

FRED KATAYAMA, CNN CORRESPONDENT: And I'm Fred Katayama.

No Christmas present for day traders. The boards of the two big exchanges are tightening day-trading requirements. That has some day traders and day-trading firms crying foul.

VARNEY: Also coming up on MONEYLINE, farm and pharmaceutical: Are the two faces of Monsanto on track to become two separate companies? We'll take a look at that.

Also ahead, prosecutors hammer a U.S. scientist linked to an espionage scandal that shook U.S.-Chinese relations: the latest on the charges against Wen Ho Lee.

And the iron fist in the calfskin glove: We'll tell you about the ruthless drive behind the LVMH luxury empire in tonight's "Bottom Line."

We'll be back.

ANNOUNCER: From CNN's New York headquarters, this is THE MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Now checking some of tonight's "MONEYLINE Movers": Ticketmaster Online CitySearch up 3 7/8. DLJ upgraded that stock to a buy. Also today, Ticketmaster named Larry Jacobson as president and COO. He is the former head of Fox Television.

Positive analysts comments lifted Tyco International two points, the most active stock on the Big Board. Lehman Brothers resumed coverage with a buy rating and it said the SEC's accounting investigation could support Tyco's position.

Harcourt General up 3 3/4. Deutsche Bank Alex Brown upgraded the book publisher to a strong buy. It said the market for educational publishers is the best it's been in 10 years.

Network Associates gained 2 5/8. BankBoston Robertson Stephens upgraded the software firm. It said concerns about fourth-quarter profits are unfounded.

After the market closed, investors slammed shares of Xerox. The company warned that its quarterly profits will fall well below expectations, and that sent the stock down more than four points in after-hours trading.

Bruce Francis joins us now with the details on this.

Bruce, what's happened?

FRANCIS: Stuart, a problem and a familiar one unfortunately for shareholders. Xerox is warning that earnings could fall short of estimates by as much as 40 percent. That could reduce Xerox's profit to little more than 39 cents a share when it reports earnings on January 25. That's less than half of what Xerox earned last year.

Let's look at the reasons why Xerox won't want to copy this quarter. Xerox says that its high-end printing business will continue to be plagued by Y2K lockdowns at big customers. And a recent reorganization of its sales force will leave higher-than-expected levels of bad debt on the books. And currency problems with both Brazil and Europe will be a drag on the bottom line. That has some analysts, like Dan Kunsler (ph) of J.P. Morgan questioning the management's ability at Xerox to execute.

Meanwhile, back at Big Blue, investors are more concerned about the news that they didn't get, specifically a cheerier outlook on Y2K. Incoming chief financial officer John Joyce briefed analysts on Thursday. And by the size of the run-up, investors probably expected some good news to come out of that meeting. Instead they got an affirmation of a previous warning about this quarter and next. Plus, a prediction that the year 2000 could be a very good one for IBM. The stock declined 8 percent over two sessions. To some analysts, though, that makes IBM a relative bargain.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KURT KING, BANC OF AMERICAN SECURITIES: I would use the pullback in IBM as a buying opportunity. We know that Y2K is the ultimate one- time event and that IBM's longer-term prospects remain very bright.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

FRANCIS: And analyst Kurt King has a 12-month target on IBM of $150 a share. So from the levels now, some decent appreciation there, Stuart. VARNEY: You got that right.

Bruce Francis, thank you very much.

Now this late news: Democratic presidential hopeful Bill Bradley has canceled a campaign appearance due to an irregular heartbeat.

Jennifer Auther has more on this -- Jennifer.

JENNIFER AUTHER, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Stuart, aides to Senator Bill Bradley have just confirmed that the senator has an irregular heartbeat. He is being treated at a hospital that they will not disclose. They will not even disclose the city. They did say, however, that Bill Bradley was at a fund-raiser here in the San Francisco Bay Area in the East Bay. He was scheduled to be here in Berkeley, where he was to announce a proposal to set aside $250 million annually to get funded from offshore revenues and tax-exempt donations from private individuals and organizations.

He was to set out an environmental plan. However, the senator has canceled afternoon events in California. He has canceled morning events in Washington state. We are told he will be able to pick up campaign on Sunday in Orlando, Florida.

However, the senator, we are told, was first diagnosed with this irregular heartbeat in 1996. So he's known about it for some time now. He is receiving treatment. He is not being hospitalized at this time.

That's all we know from here at this time.

Stuart, back to you.

VARNEY: Jennifer Auther with that late-breaking news.

Thank you, Jennifer.

You are watching MONEYLINE, and we'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: There were some very big-name stocks that managed to hit 52-week highs today, and they include: American Express, Oracle, America Online, General Electric and Wal-Mart -- new highs, all of them.

In tonight's other corporate headlines: General Motors will buy a 20 percent stake in Fuji Heavy Industries for $1.4 billion. Fuji manufacturers Subaru cars and trucks. GM finished the day: down nearly three-quarters of a point.

A British newspaper and magazine publisher rejected a cash takeover bid from Gannett. News Communications and media said Gannett's undisclosed amount is just too low. Shares of Gannett fell nearly 1 1/4 but gained nearly five in the past two sessions, after the company issued a positive outlook for fourth-quarter profits and revenues.

The pressure is on for the board of directors at Monsanto. Its stock jumped nearly four percent today, on a "Wall Street Journal" report that the life sciences firm could take dramatic steps to boost its sagging stock price. Monsanto finished the day up 1 9/16, at 43 13/16.

And as Allan Dodds Frank reports, investors are hoping for a breakup.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ALLAN DODDS FRANK, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Is St. Louis- based Monsanto ready to transform itself into separate agricultural and pharmaceutical firms, or sell out? Those questions faced the company's directors as they convened today at an undisclosed location in Chicago. Wall Street has been pining for a breakup since Monsanto failed to merge with American Home Products last year at $57 a share, an offer 30 percent above Monsanto's closing price today.

Many analyst say the hot new arthritis drug Celebrex, controlled by the company's Searle unit, could make Monsanto worth far more if it were valued as a pharmaceutical firm.

BILL YOUNG, DONALDSON, LUFKIN & JENRETTE: If Monsanto were to split up AG versus Searle, I don't think it would be too long until the vultures, meaning other large pharmaceutical companies, would go in and make a play to take hold of Searle.

FRANK: Monsanto sells nearly $2.75 billion worth of pharmaceutical products and takes in more than $4 billion a year from agriculture. And while its herbicide, Roundup, is the biggest selling weed killer, the company's genetically modified crops have been meeting increasing consumer resistance.

WILLIAM FIALA, CHEMICAL ANALYST, EDWARD JONES: They bet the farm in AG biotechnology. They invested billions and billions of dollars, leveraged up their balance sheet, and it's not quite panning out. So they're looking for someone with some financial strength to team up with.

FRANK: Monsanto remains strong in agriculture, but its competition is increasing.

TOM BRAKEL, METHA PARTNERS: The competitive landscape has changed in the agribusiness dramatically I think last week, when Astrazeneca and Novartis put their agribusiness together, creating a very large competitor also in the core protection area, which should be a concern for Monsanto.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FRANK: Analysts usually mention DuPont and Aspirin Behr of Germany as two companies big enough to buy all of Monsanto, and there is Pfizer, which now markets Celebrex with Monsanto. If Pfizer loses its fight with American Home Products for Warner-Lambert, it might decide it has no choice but to go after Monsanto -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Allan Dodds Frank reporting. Thank you.

Now to Wen Ho Lee. Criminal charges tonight against the nuclear scientist accused of a security breach that rocked Washington. CNN has learned that prosecutors have filed a 59-count indictment against Wen Ho Lee, who was arrested today. The indictment charges him with mishandling classified information from the Los Alamos Nuclear Laboratory. Officials linked him to alleged Chinese attempts to steal U.S. nuclear secrets. But Lee has not been charged with spying, and prosecutors now say lack of proof makes such a charge unlikely. No reaction from China, where government offices are closed for the night.

And another story of suspected espionage topping our MONEYLINE news digest: U.S. investigators hope to find out whether an alleged Russian spy had inside help in bugging the State Department. Officials think it is possible, because Stanislav Gusev apparently needed more than one visit to plant the device, which also required maintenance.

Russia is finding a sympathetic ear in Beijing. Jiang Zemin and Boris Yeltsin complained today about U.S. domination of world affairs. The leaders wrapped up a two-day summit, promising mutual support on Chechnya and Taiwan.

In Cuba, massive government choreographed demonstrations again, demanding the United States return a rescued Cuban boy. Lawyers for 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez say they'll file papers requesting he be granted U.S. asylum.

Also today, the second deadly air accident for the military in just two days. A U.S. C-130 crash-landed in Kuwait, attempting an emergency landing after its landing gear malfunctioned. Three of the 96 on board were killed.

President Clinton today praised the peacetime bravery of the nation's military.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAM J. CLINTON, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We do not have to be at war for that to be dangerous work. Most people have no earthly idea how dangerous it is to fly those fast planes, and to fire those powerful weapons and to undergo on rigorous training that they have to undergo.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VARNEY: And new information on another fatal crash, based on that controversial cockpit tape from EgyptAir flight 990. Federal investigators say there's no evidence of an explosion or mechanical problems in the crew's conversations.

In a week when it seemed nothing went right for the U.S. in space, a success for a leading-edge commercial competitor. Europe's new Ariane 5 rocket lifted off today from FrenchGuyana in Latin America on its first mission. The smooth launch was a triumph for ArianeSpace, the European company leading the world's commercial satellite launch market.

There's much more coming up, and yes, you are watching MONEYLINE.

We'll be back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Here are some of the stocks hitting new 52-week lows today: Dave & Buster's restaurant chain, Del Monte Foods, General Mills, U.S. Bancorp and Penzoil.

A major legal victory for gunmakers tonight. A Connecticut judge dismissed a $100 million lawsuit brought by the city of Bridgeport against the gun industry. The judge ruled the city has no standing to sue. Today's dismissal doesn't mean that troubles of the industry are over. Nineteen other suits are still working their way through the courts.

Still to come on MONEYLINE: financial stocks push the Dow industrials ahead. Investors breathe a sigh of relief on another sign of low inflation. But day traders not exactly celebrating, as the Nasdaq and Big Board look to tighten their trading rules.

Plus, from Gwyneth Paltrow and Elton John to these supermodels, LVMH brands catch the eyes of the rich and famous. But will the love affair with this luxury goods empire last? "The Bottom Line" still to come on MONEYLINE.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANNOUNCER: MONEYLINE continues. Here again, Staurt Varney.

VARNEY: In tonight's headlines, defying predictions and even gravity, the Nasdaq blazes into record territory for the fourth time this week.

The big tech winner: another tiny company with no earnings but plenty of buzz. FreeMarkets, the latest IPO firecracker.

And "The Bottom Line" on LVMH. It sells luxury in a bottle and style in a bag.

But our top story tonight: a hard-charging rally on news that hit Wall Street before the opening bell. Stocks pushed higher all across the board on an inflation-friendly economic report. And they got an even bigger push late in the day as oil prices tumbled.

The Dow industrials jumped nearly 90 points, ending the day at 11,224. Volume on the big board is strong at 987 million shares.

The Nasdaq hit its fourth record of the week and its 51st of the year, up another 26 to end at 3620. Volume not as brisk as the past two sessions, which were record-setting, but still busy -- more than 1.6 billion shares.

The enthusiasm extended to the bond market. The 30-year Treasury gained 22 ticks, the yield down to 6.16 percent.

The catalyst for this rally: just a .2 percent rise in producer prices last month. And not counting energy and food, prices would have been flat.

Greg Clarkin joins us now from the New York Stock Exchange for more on today's run-up -- Greg.

CLARKIN: Well, Stuart, as you mentioned, the buying really accelerated in the final hour or so of trading. Investors seizing on hopes the Federal Reserve will hold off on another interest rate hike. Now financial stocks were the big beneficiaries there, but one big loser did emerge after the bell, and that is Xerox. The photocopying giant warned fourth-quarter earnings could be as much as 40 percent below Wall Street forecasts. Xerox blames weak sales in the U.S. and Europe and the strong dollar. And the stock really taking a beating in after-hours trading, down more than $4 for about a 15 to 18 percent drop on that stock.

Now back to today's regular session. Losers on the big board ran neck and neck with winners. The number of stocks hitting new 52-week highs, 87, versus the number of new lows, 324. Some big Dow movers, IBM fell nearly $5 and has lost eight percent on earnings concerns. American Express and J.P. Morgan both surged. General Electric gained another five, and ExxonMobil fell more than three as oil prices sank.

Light sweet crude fell 92 cents a barrel on word Iraq will resume oil exports in an oil-for-food deal with the United Nations.

That's going to do it from here, Stuart, let's send it back to you.

VARNEY: Greg, not much action in those big-name tech stocks today? Nothing going on there at all?

CLARKIN: Exactly, Stuart, record number 51 for the Nasdaq this year was really made with the absence of the big-name tech stocks, with the exception of Sun Microsystems, which posted a nice gain. But Dell, Cisco, Microsoft and Intel really just kind of floundering around a bit. And analysts are saying that's what we've seen in the past couple of sessions, some of the strength in the Nasdaq really coming from the Internet-related stocks, the stocks that make equipment for the Internet as well as software and the like. That's what really seems to be carrying the Nasdaq these days.

VARNEY: Greg Clarkin reporting from the big board.

Well, once again it was a week dominated by tech stocks. While the Nasdaq composite bounded from record to record, the Dow actually lost ground, down a fraction on the week that is. But the Nasdaq jumped nearly three percent and the S&P 500 fell more than one percent. But for the second straight day, the biggest winners were not the old tech standbys but the new kids on the block. IPO mania continues to grip investors, and the result has been some of the splashiest market debuts ever. Today, business-to-business online auctioneer FreeMarkets went public at $48 a share. It hit a high of $293. It closed at $280. That's a gain of 483 percent, a stunning debut, yes, just a day after VA Linux shattered all previous IPO records.

Steve Young has more on the latest IPO sensation.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

YOUNG (voice-over): Offering just an 11 percent slice to the public, FreeMarkets.com Friday triggered an IPO free fall that sent its stock spiralling higher. It's corporate America's version of eBay, but it runs in reverse. FreeMarkets lets big corporations get the lowest prices by having suppliers bid for the business.

ERIC YUPIN, BANKBOSTON ROBERTSON STEPHENS: It's going to change industry structures. I mean, we believe it's going to lower procurement costs, it's going to lower product cost, and it's going to increase the capacity utilization and productivity of industries. The ramifications of this kind of solution are extremely profound, hence the investor appetite and the multiples we're seeing, which will give rise to huge companies.

YOUNG: FreeMarkets is the first publicly traded company in the business-to-business Internet auction game, and the momentum as a so- called "first mover" is important. But it has competition from a subsidiary of the EVS, and it's unclear if FreeMarkets' patent claims will keep other companies from copying its business model. That's because the claims are pending, but they haven't been issued yet by the patent office. The problem could affect other Internet IPOs in the pipeline.

JAMES IBESTER, GIBSON, DUNN & CRUTCHER: This isn't just a FreeMarket issue. This is an issue that's applicable to many, many of these offerings. Until the patents not only have been issued by the patent office and then tested in the waters of the federal courts, it's going to be very difficult to assess the value of the patent protection people are able to get on essentially ways of doing business.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

YOUNG: The patent office has been bogged down by a flood of patent claims filed in the last year on doing business over the Internet. That means it will be several years at least before investors know whether Internet companies with pending patents are nothing more than risky business -- Stuart.

VARNEY: And we'll be waiting. Steve Young reporting.

Well, FreeMarkets wasn't the day's only blockbuster IPO. ESpeed, an electronic trading software maker that was spun off by Cantor Fitzgerald, that nearly doubled. El Sitio climbed more than 17 1/4. That is a network of Web sites for Spanish and Portuguese speakers. And eBenx more than doubled to close at 44 7/8. That company makes software for paying medical bills online.

But for VA Linux, day two on Wall Street was far less profitable than day one. Yesterday's IPO star was today's rather large loser. It was down 21 1/4. However, if you were lucky enough to get the stock at the IPO price, you are still sitting on a 626 percent return. Investors cashed in on other Linux stocks as well. Red Hat and Andover.net both slumped, Corel fell 8 3/4. It was the most active stock on the Nasdaq.

Coming up, more on IPO mania. We'll talk to a fund manager, Linda Killian, who's at the center of the IPO action.

And we'll hear what brought Elton John and Gwyneth Paltrow to a Manhattan soiree. Could it have been the champagne? We'll have "The Bottom Line" on that one for you.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: It's been a breathtaking period to be in IPOs, and that's an understatement. With FreeMarkets today coming out with its stunning issue, hot on the heels of yesterday's record-breaking showing from VA Linux, the average IPO is up nearly 200 percent this year, and Web-related issues have posted gains of 250 percent.

Our next guest has been at the heart of the action. Her fund invests exclusively in IPOs, and her fund is up 97 percent this year. We're now joined by Linda Killian, manager of the IPO Plus Aftermarket Fund.

Linda, welcome back.

LINDA KILLIAN, IPO PLUS AFTERMARKET FUND: Thank you.

VARNEY: There's something I don't understand. Just take VA Linux for example. It comes out priced at $30 a share, it goes to 240. Why wasn't it priced at 50 or 100 or 150?

KILLIAN: Pricing of IPOs is as much of an art as a science. If they had in fact, the underwriters had priced it at 80, their entire book of orders may have disappeared.

VARNEY: May have, but we don't know that. In the meantime, the company didn't get the money. It was the underwriters who got the money, and the friends and family and insiders who held shares at the offering price, not the company. They didn't get the money.

KILLIAN: You make a good point. And that's why there are some people who advocate Dutch actions for IPOs.

VARNEY: Is that likely to come?

KILLIAN: There is one company that does the Dutch auction method and that's W.R. Hambrecht. And they've done several deals.

VARNEY: Is there general dissatisfaction with the pricing of IPOs at this stage of the market?

KILLIAN: Not if you got in at the offering price.

VARNEY: Does your fund get in at the offering price?

KILLIAN: We buy both on the offering and in the aftermarket. That's why we're called the IPO Plus Aftermarket Fund.

VARNEY: Now, how are you able to get in at the market price, whereas an individual investors, like myself for example, could not.

KILLIAN: We are an institutional investor, and we also follow the companies very closely from a research standpoint. We research every IPO that comes to market. We have researched over 500 IPOs this year. And from that standpoint, the IPOs themselves, the management of the company, would like to have investors such as ourselves who are basically longer-term holders of IPOs.

VARNEY: So they are pleasing you?

KILLIAN: Well, we hope so.

VARNEY: You are there to be pleased is, right? Is that the way it is?

KILLIAN: We hope so. There's tremendous demand for IPOs, and no investor, whether they're a powerful individual investors or a very large institutional investor, is ever going to get all the shares of an IPO they want.

VARNEY: How much longer is this going to go on for?

KILLIAN: That's a very good question. Certainly we're seeing a very active pipeline for IPOs. It's at about 200 that are expected to price during -- sometime during the first quarter.

I expect that the IPO market will continue to move along simply because there are so many very exciting companies that are in the pipeline, and there are so many businesses that are just poised to really start to flourish, like business-to-business activities on the Internet, genomics, I would say finance.com. Those are just three of the areas that I think are very fruitful.

VARNEY: In your fund, though, you are allowed to short a stock, aren't you? Like to short an IPO, you can do that?

KILLIAN: Yes, we can.

VARNEY: And in are you shorting some stocks, some IPOs, not in the three areas you mentioned?

KILLIAN: We believe in risk management at the IPO fund, and, therefore, what we do when we evaluate companies from a fundamental standpoint, when we identify companies that have particularly poor outlooks and business models, we put them on our list to short, and we do short stocks.

VARNEY: Fair enough. Linda Killian, many thanks for being with us.

KILLIAN: Thank you.

VARNEY: OK.

Coming up on MONEYLINE, they have a reputation as cowboys who borrow huge sums of money and place risky bets on the market. But are the rules about to change for day traders? That story after the break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Now lets check some of tonight's other movers for you.

Home Depot up more than 1 1/2, and that's a new 52-week high. ING Barings raised its price target to $99 a share, based on the company's new merchandising efforts.

Ciena up 10 5/16. The telecom equipment maker beat fourth- quarter profit estimates by a penny, and it said revenues could grow more than 50 percent next year. And Lehmann Brothers upgraded its stock to a buy rating.

Nortel Networks up more than 5 1/2. It will supply wireless network equipment to AT&T, in a deal valued at $600 million. The company would not comment on a "Wall Street Journal" article that said it may buy Qtera for $3 billion in stock.

And a strong day for the steel industry. Lehmann Brothers upgraded several companies. It cited rising steel prices, positive seasonal factors, and weak stock prices.

It was a Friday to celebrate on Wall Street, but some investors were not exactly in the mood. In the hopes of limiting the risks associated with day trading, the boards of the NYSE and the parent of the Nasdaq stock market approved a plan to tighten day-trading requirements.

Fred Katayama has more on what it could all mean to this group of investors.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KATAYAMA (voice-over): At issue: What some regulators see as the excessive borrowing by day traders. To curb the risks, the Big Board and the parent of the Nasdaq proposed rules to boost margin requirements for day traders, defined as those who buy and sell the same stock four times or more in five days.

AMY BUTTE, ANALYST, BEAR STERNS: It is going to be more expensive for people to become day traders. Therefore, we should see a little bit of a dampening impact.

KATAYAMA: Specifically, the exchanges propose to dramatically boost the minimum balance day traders must keep in their account to $25,000 from 2,000. If it falls below that level, they won't be allowed to trade.

(on camera): The proposed rules will not bar traders from lending money to each other to meet margin requirements, but it could make overnight lending more difficult. Traders will not be allowed to withdraw funds for two business days.

HARVEY HOUTKIN, CEO, ALL-TECH DIRECT: The demonizing of people lending one another money seems almost ironic in a country that is built on free trade, banking, letters of credit, commercial paper, and everything else.

KATAYAMA (voice-over): Day trading has come under increasing scrutiny after day trader Mark Barton, who lost thousands of dollars, killed 12 people in Atlanta. Day traders like John Picinich (ph) contend the proposed measures discriminate against them.

JOHN PICINICH, DAY TRADER: The more rules they impose, the worse it is for us. I mean, we know what we got to do.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Can you limit a guy from doing what he wants? You should not be able to. I mean, this is what America is all about.

KATAYAMA: The rules must be approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

KATAYAMA: There was one proposal the industry welcomed. The exchanges offered to allow traders to borrow up to four times the amount of cash in their accounts, that's up from two times currently -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Fred Katayama reporting. Thank you, Fred.

BellSouth is trying hard to capitalize on the wireless boom in Europe. The regional phone company teamed up with KPN Telecom to buy Germany's number-three mobile phone operator. BellSouth will take a $9 billion loan from KPN to purchase the rest of E-Plus shares it doesn't already own.

Earlier on CNNfn, BellSouth's chief executive said the deal is good news for shareholders.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DUANE ACKERMAN, CHMN. AND CEO, BELLSOUTH: When you look at the German market, it's a very attractive market. It's the ten-largest countries in Europe that's probably the lowest penetrated of all, so there's great opportunity for growth. So we're really not looking at keeping anyone out. We were simply looking at the deal that positioned our shareholders the best for the long haul. (END VIDEO CLIP)

VARNEY: Shares of BellSouth ended the day unchanged. KPN Telecom soared 8 3/4. But the deal is a blow to France Telecom, which sank 10 points. It had already made an agreement to buy E-Plus, and said it will now review other options.

Other corporate headlines tonight: America Online jumped more than 6 1/2 to an all-time high after SalomonSmith Barney analyst Rick Church said a he expected AOL to unveil an alliance with Wal-Mart. Wal-Mart shares up 1 5/8. AOL and Wal-Mart declined comment on the analyst's note.

On the drug front, American Home Products knocked down reports that it's looking to buy Pharmacia and Upjohn. "The Financial Times" reported that AHP is eyeing Pharmacia as a fallback plan, in case it loses out on its bid for Warner-Lambert. Pfizer has mounted a major challenge for Warner, but AHP says it's fully committed to that deal. AHP shares up more than 1 1/4.

Still to come on MONEYLINE: If it's European, expensive, and stylish, odds are LVMH makes it. "The Bottom Line" on the ultimate status stock.

That's just ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: And now to our regular Friday feature, "The Bottom Line." It's a segment that usually focuses on American companies on the move and in the news. But tonight, we look at a European firm whose four initials are synonymous with luxury: LVMH, the French empire behind world-class brands like Moet Chandon, Louis Vuitton and Christian Dior, and run by a Frenchman known as one of Europe's most ruthless dealmakers.

Peter Viles has the story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PETER VILES, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): He's known as the king of luxury, the pope of fashion, and this week in New York, Bernard Arnaud held court as only he can.

HILLARY CLINTON, FIRST LADY OF THE UNITED STATES: President Chiraq came up to me and said, you must attend the opening of the most fantastic building.

VILES: The building is the New York headquarters of Arnaud's luxury empire, LVMH, a monument to the worldwide popularity of luxury goods. From Tokyo to Tampa, the world now wears Christian Dior, carries Louis Vuitton luggage and drinks Dom Perignon champagne -- all brands Arnaud has brought together in a run of ruthless dealmaking that belies his elegant image.

BERNARD ARNAUD, CHAIRMAN, LVMH: Oh yes, it's a lot of fun. This is a business which is really completely different, because it's a mixture between creativity and organization, and I think that's what we are very much good at.

VILES: To the shock of the European elite, Arnaud brought in young designers like John Galliano to jump start aging labels.

JOHN: He's rejuvenated these labels -- Givenchy, Dior, and Louis Vuitton -- by hiring really smart, good, talented, young designers. I mean, he really has turned it around. I mean, Louis Vuitton was just a luggage label, all right, and now it does everything; it's one of the hippest labels around.

VILES: And when he goes shopping, Arnaud usually gets what he wants. This year, he took over the British auction house Phillips, watchmakers Zenith International and Tag Heuer, the British shirtmaker Thomas Pink, and teaming with Prada, took a majority of the Italian fashion house Fendi. He did fail, however, in his bid for Gucci, but is now said to have his eye now on Giorgio Armani and Calvin Klein.

DAVID VIMERCATI, SALOMONSMITH BARNEY: I think that LVMH will continue pursuing this growth-through-acquisition strategy, and of course, Mr. Arnaud has been seen talking to Armani and to other designers.

VILES (on camera): When Arnaud is not making designers offers they cannot refuse, he is rolling out new brands like this one, Sephora, a line of makeup stores that has quickly become LVMH's biggest online retail outlet as well.

(voice-over): What this all adds up to is an $8 billion-a-year company, supporting a stock that has more than doubled in the past year.

But can the run continue? The answer lies partly in the strength of the Asian recovery. Asia accounts for a third of LVMH sales. LVMH trades in the U.S. as an ADR, which means it is thinly traded. Investors are also buying exposure to the euro currency.

European fund manager Scott Clemons has his doubts.

SCOTT CLEMONS, BROWN BROTHERS HARRIMAN: We believe LVMH, although a very high-quality company and very well managed, no doubt, is nonetheless fully valued. As a matter of fact, on our numbers, the shares are as expensive as some of the products they sell.

VILES: The other question is, how long will the global love affair with luxury last? Even at ground zero in the fashion and luxury world, there are doubts about that.

PALTROW: I think it'll continue as long as the stock market's bullish. But I think when that stops, the fascination will probably wane a little bit.

VILES: Peter Viles, CNN Financial News, New York.

(END VIDEOTAPE) VARNEY: Up next: "Ahead of the Curve," just some of what you need to know tonight before the markets open next week.

You're watching MONEYLINE.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Checking some of what could move the markets next week: Investors will have another inflation report to look at on Tuesday with the release of the consumer price index. Also due out: retail sales for November, the latest figures on the manufacturing and housing sectors and on international trade.

On the earnings front, several big-name firms expected to report include Oracle, FDX, Best Buy, Nike and Circuit City.

And keep an eye on Foundry Networks. After the bell, they announced a two-for-one stock split. The networking equipment maker went public just three months ago. In after-hours trading, its stock soared more than 17 points, to $295 a share.

This programming note: Be sure to join us on Monday when we begin a two week special look at the new economy: Is it a boom without end? We'll talk to the nation's top CEOs, policy makers and economists from across the country to explore this raging debate. The future of the stock market and the nation's prosperity depend on the answer. So join us please for "The New Economy," starting Monday, 6:30 p.m. Eastern here on CNN.

That's MONEYLINE for this Friday night and another business week. I'm Stuart Varney. And we thank you for joining us. Good night from New York.

"CROSSFIRE" is next.

urn:contentItem:5VNG-VXV1-JCMN-Y1V2-00000-00Investors focused on themes are making 5 big mistakes. Here's how UBS says they can be avoided.2019-03-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:48ZLexisNexisInvestors focused on themes are making 5 big mistakes. Here's how UBS says they can be avoided.Marley Jay

Mar 17, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) REUTERS/Brendan McDermid UBS says there are five common mistakes that thematic investors need to avoid for their strategies to work. Laura Kane, the firm's head of Americas thematic research, offers advice mostly centered around the patience investors should exhibit when deciding when to buy or sell. She also lays out how investors can avoid each of the five pitfalls she outlines. Investing based on themes requires patience and confidence, according to one of UBS's top researchers.

But actually abiding by those principles is easier said than done. Laura Kane — the head of Americas thematic research for the firm's chief investment office — recognizes this, and has compiled a list of five common mistakes made by thematic investors of all types[1]. She also lays out how investors can avoid each pitfall.1) Chasing fadsKane says it's vital to understand the difference between a long-term trend that's going to endure, and a fad that attracts tremendous hype and then fades almost as fast. Bitcoin, she says, is a fad. Meanwhile, changes in global demographics are an important trend in her view. Kane writes that as the global population is growing rapidly and concentrating in cities, while the populations in developed countries are aging. Those have major investing consequences. "We will see the need for healthcare technologies to cope with an aging population, as well as demand for more energy-efficient infrastructure in growing emerging cities," she wrote. How UBS says investors can avoid this pitfall: Investors should focus on the three main "inescapable forces" that should transpire, regardless of the business cycle: Population growth — By 2050, the global population will have surged to 10 billion from 7.5 billion at present time. Aging — By 2030, individuals older than 60 will outnumber those 25 or younger in developed countries. Urbanization — By 2050, UBS expects that 68% of the world's population will live in cities.2) Being too earlyEveryone wants to be the first to identify a trend or a great trade, but there is often no advantage in being the first company to disrupt an industry. That means that, as an investor, you may not want to bet on a company that is shaking up a field because it might ultimately be beaten out by later competitors. After all, Amazon wasn't the first online bookseller[2], and if you'd invested in MySpace and passed on Facebook, you've probably been dealing with some regrets. Kane says that should be on investors' minds as they consider investing in ride-hailing companies ahead of the expected IPOs of Uber[3] and Lyft in the next few months[4]. "The shape of the ride-hailing industry is still being defined, as many variables continue to evolve," she wrote."Until we get greater clarity on regulatory, liability, and even tax consequences, it will be difficult to choose winners in this space." How UBS says investors can avoid this pitfall: UBS says traders should let the dust settle in fledgling industries before making any specific decisions.3) Making just one betAn investor might be overwhelmingly confident about or interested in one single theme, but Kane says they shouldn't put all their eggs in one basket because that's likely to lead to volatility. If a trader insists upon a single theme, Kane recommends they be careful with the rest of their your portfolio to make sure its risks and rewards are well-balanced. How UBS says investors can avoid this pitfall: UBS says traders should diversify holdings so as not to get caught with outsized exposure to a failing idea.4) Not looking under the hoodThematic investors sometimes buy into any company that fits into their favored idea. But Kane says they need to look carefully at every company — especially if they're new. "A company could be exposed to an attractive theme, but that does not automatically mean it is a good investment," she writes. In addition, Kane advises investors to look hard at issues like corporate governance and culture as well as financial measurements. How UBS says investors can avoid this pitfall: UBS said traders should do exhaustive homework on new entrants to industries and themes they're pursuing.5) Selling too soonKane writes that investors often sell too quickly because they're afraid of future pain. But that haste can cause them to miss out on eventual gains that might dwarf their present losses. "The temptation is high to walk away from long-term ideas that temporarily underperform," she says. "We advise against trying to jump in and out of long-term thematic investments." Kane adds that over the last six decades, a buy-and-hold strategy for the S...00[5] has worked much better than trying to time market highs and lows. That's illustrated by the chart below. Jeremy Grantham, the widely respected investor who successfully predicted the last two financial bubbles, has made a similar point[6]: In a market bubble, getting out of too soon can be just as bad as getting out too late.How UBS says investors can avoid this pitfall: UBS says traders shouldn't abandon a long-term theme because of modest setbacks. It could hurt them just as much to get out too early than wait too long to exit. urn:contentItem:5TK4-77F1-JBJ7-N4F1-00000-00Investors get ready for the Trump dump2018-10-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:48ZLexisNexisInvestors get ready for the Trump dumpKaren Maley

Donald Trump's gripe with Beijing extends well beyond trade issues to concerns about China's confrontational military stance, with huge implications for major US corporates, and particularly the tech giants.

Investors are already bracing for the next set of monster waves to break over them.

Share prices of both Amazon and Google parent company Alphabet slumped in US after-hours trading, after the two US e-commerce giants reported disappointing revenue growth. (The other two big tech titans - Apple and Facebook - report their results next week.)

What was curious about the savage after-hours sell-off - which saw Amazon's share price drop 7.7 per cent, while that of Alphabet fell more than 3 per cent - was that there was much to celebrate in the third-quarter results of both companies.

Amazon.com posted its second straight quarter of record profitability, while Alphabet's net profit surged by nearly 37 per cent in the three months to September.

This suggests that investors remained concerned that the big US tech giants could become collateral damage as the rift between Beijing and Washington deepens.

Hopes are waning that a face-to-face meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping on the sidelines of the Group of 20 leaders in Buenos Aires next month could lead to a quick resolution to escalating trade tensions.

The Wall Street Journal reports that the US is refusing to resume trade negotiations with China until Beijing comes up with a concrete proposal that addresses Washington's complaint about forced technology transfers.

At the same time, investors are becoming increasingly convinced that Washington's gripe with Beijing extends well beyond trade issues to concerns about China's confrontational military stance. And these could have huge implications for major US corporates, and particularly the tech giants.

In a hard-hitting speech earlier this month, US Vice President Mike Pence called US companies to reconsider business practices in the world's second largest economy, that give China access to sensitive technology or which abet what he called "Beijing's oppression".

For instance, he said, "Google should immediately end development of the Dragonfly app that will strengthen Communist Party censorship and compromise the privacy of Chinese customers."

In his latest investment newsletter, independent strategist Russell Napier argues that US tech stocks are already coming under pressure from these heightened geopolitical tensions between Washington and Beijing.

The new 'Cold War'

"While there are many reasons why technology stocks are falling, the dawning of this new relationship between business and the state is a key driver for lower share prices."

But, as he points out, there will be other casualties of this "Cold War" between the US and China.

"Many Asian countries have lived under the US defence umbrella while freely trading with and investing in China. This was a wonderful combination as defence spending could be kept low, but those same countries got to enjoy all the benefits of trading with a large and rapidly growing economic behemoth."

But, he warns, "this was a recipe for economic success that has now ended as the new Cold War, a war explicitly aimed at containing the China 'threat' has been declared".

This has huge implications for investors, because, as he notes, "it is unrealistic to expect the countries of Asia under the US defence umbrella to continue to get the use of that umbrella while trading freely with China.

"The end of that relationship means not just lower growth but higher risk premiums as any Cold War inevitably entails some hotter episodes where those pursuing the conflict meet."

Napier also warns financial stocks - such as banks - are brutally exposed.

Although the US share market has moved back into positive territory for the year, the KBW Bank index - the benchmark stock index for the US banking sector - has plunged 9.3 per cent in the past month, leaving it down 10 per cent for the year.

"While other factors are operating to cause the collapse of financials share prices ... the newly accelerated collapse recognises that such companies are increasingly in the front line of the new Cold War," Napier writes.

"In a world where the state plays a much bigger role in the allocation of capital, whether under the guise of macro prudential regulation or to support a cold war, it is not realistic to expect private sector corporations to be paid a high fee to accept those state directions."

Daily roundup of research and analysis from The Globe and Mail's market strategist Scott Barlow

Citi commodity analyst Aakash Doshi believes the gold price has further to run (my emphasis),

Texte/Text

"While nominal gold prices have posted fresh records north of $2,000/oz in 3Q'20, inflation-adjusted gold prices bouncing around $750-800/oz still remain 30% below the 1980 peaks above $1,000/oz. Given Fed policy at the ZLB [zero lower bound] ... a bearish US$ environment, and heightened macro uncertainty across the real economy (e.g., high sector dispersion), we believe investors will likely make a push towards record bullion prices in real terms over the next calendar year. We lift the 2021E base case gold price forecast by ~$300/oz, versus our early July update, to a record $2,275/oz."

***

BoA strategist Savita Subramanian published an investor guide to the upcoming U.S. election,

"A contested vote: Could drive 5% downside for the S&P 500. At least that's what happened in 2000 ... Taxes: Biden's proposal to increase taxes could cost as much as 9 ppt [percentage points] of S&P 500 earnings ... A Biden victory is not an automatic negative for Health Care as long as Congress remains split. In fact, our Life Sciences and Diagnostic Tools team sees a Biden administration, either with or without a split Congress, as sector positive. Industrials: Perceptions of tighter regulations under Biden hurting Industrials could be offset by an infrastructure bill, which may have a higher likelihood under a Dem sweep... "

"@SBarlow_ROB BoA: Investors guide to U.S. election" - (research excerpt) Twitter

***

Jefferies strategist Christopher Wood is bearish on large-cap technology stocks,

"For if Big Tech's business models were massive beneficiaries of the economic lockdowns, as has clearly been the case this year as demonstrated by these companies' earnings reports as well as their surging share prices, it follows that the same companies will be relative losers if the world goes back to normal sooner rather than later which is what [we]still expects to happen ... there is a more mundane explanation for why value should now be expected to enjoy at least an extended period of relative outperformance. For that is what should happen if cyclical momentum continues to build, in line with [our] base case, as the virus continues to prove less virulent than previously feared"

"@SBarlow_ROB Jefferies: "For if Big Tech's business models were massive beneficiaries of the economic lockdowns ... it follows that the same companies will be relative losers if the world goes back to normal" - (research excerpt) Twitter

"Are value stocks ready for a revival?" - Fidelity

***

Citi's global economics team is still bearish,

"Rebound does not equal recovery. The path to full recovery might be much more gradual in most economies after Q3, and riddled with uncertainty. We expect global level of output to reach pre-pandemic levels in mid-2021 at the earliest ... markets remain largely detached from economic fundamentals. As equity markets remain in "euphoria" according to Citi's model, the risk of a correction in the coming months remains elevated. There is no shortage of upcoming risk events, such as the second wave of the pandemic, vaccine development, US elections and Brexit to name a few, that could act as catalysts.'

***

HSBC analyst James Pomeroy believes a much larger share of our lives is moving to virtual reality,

"Even though the initial application for VR was for immersive gaming (as seen from the 5m units of PSVR being sold globally, reported by Sony, which makes it the biggest selling VR headset to date), today VR in general is beginning to make inroads for virtualising many other non-gaming experiences too through wireless headsets like the Oculus Quest. Applications we have observed include: social VR, working from home in VR, education, conferences, concerts and festivals (Burning Man 2020 is in VR this year), sports, theatre, museums, medicine and fitness - all without physical travel. VR has the potential to virtualise previous experiences where there was only an analogue counterpart and for which you had to physically travel. This can push more of the global GDP to digital."

"@SBarlow_ROB HSBC thinks everything's going VR" - (research excerpt) Twitter

A roundup of what The Globe and Mail s market strategist Scott Barlow is reading today on the Web

FULL TEXT

A roundup of what The Globe and Mail's market strategist Scott Barlow is reading today on the Web

I've probably learned more about markets from former Merrill Lynch chief quantitative strategist Richard Bernstein than anyone else. Now the head of the company he founded, RB Advisors, Mr. Bernstein's latest research report (free to read on the corporate website) urges investors to "dust off the fire extinguishers" for their portfolios as risks rise,

"Investors seem to be following the historical precedent and are becoming increasingly bullish despite a deterioration in underlying fundamentals. With that in mind, it seems prudent to dust off the fire extinguishers Investors often assume their portfolios are diversified, however, asset classes that might provide significant portfolio diversification in one period might be quite ineffective in another Ignoring the smoke alarm #1: analysts seem unaware of deteriorating profits."

The eight-page report is worth reading in its entirety for context.

"Dusting off the "fire extinguishers"" - http://rbadvisors.com/images/pdfs/Dusting_off_the_fire_extinguishers.pdf

"Awfully high' risks of a global recession in the next 12-18 months, Moody's chief economist says" - https://www.cnbc.com/2019/10/16/global-economy-awfully-high-chance-of-economic-recession-moodys-says.html?__source=twitter%7Cmain

***

Bloomberg reports that "Canada's real estate market is in full recovery mode," but BMO economist Robert Kavcic believes that the housing market stimulus from lower borrowing costs is played out for now,

"Canadian 5-yr fixed mortgage rates plunged by roughly 100 bps from the turn of the year to recent lows. This was a major factor driving the rebound in national housing activity. Now, longer-term bond yields have backed up alongside some favourable global developments. As a result, the housing market is probably squeezing out the last of this stimulus."

urn:contentItem:5TKD-YW51-J9XT-P47V-00000-00Investors Offered Access To Fast Growing Medical Cannabis Sector With eToro2018-10-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:48ZLexisNexisInvestors Offered Access To Fast Growing Medical Cannabis Sector With eToro

LONDON: Mondo Visione has issued the following news release: New eToro CopyPortfolio comprises leading North American listed biotech companies specialising in medical marijuana CopyPortfolio re-opened due to popular demand Initial launch in September gained 1,000 investors in less than two weeks Global investment platform eToro announces that it will reopen access to its Cannabis Care CopyPortfolio on Thursday 1st November to coincide with changes in the UK allowing specialist doctors to prescribe medical cannabis. Investors in the Cannabis Care CopyPortfolio will get managed access to a group of leading biotech companies listed in North America specialising in medical cannabis. Medical cannabis is a fast-growing industry following a series of regulatory changes which have increased access to marijuana.

Growth in the global legal cannabis market is being led by the US and Canada, however, Europe is also following suit. The industry is projected to reach $57 billion worldwide by 2027*. Yoni Assia, CEO and Co-founder of eToro, comments: “Despite the already impressive growth, many believe that the medical marijuana market is only just beginning to make its mark. The industry is expected to advance considerably in the next few years, as the legalisation of medical use around the world becomes more widespread and the number of adults living in legal use markets increases.” Today’s news follows the initial launch in September which saw 1,000 clients invest in less than two weeks. The decision to re-open access to the CopyPortfolio follows significant demand from clients. It will close to new investors at midnight on the day that the CopyPortfolio reaches a total of 2,000 investors. The Cannabis Care CopyPortfolio is managed by eToro’s Investment Committee. The CopyPortfolio currently invests in 10 companies, including businesses which grow medical marijuana, develop cannabis-based pharmaceuticals, and other companies involved in the sector. Yoni Assia added: “Our aim is to make it as easy as possible for investors to access the assets they want. The demand for investment exposure to the rapidly growing medical cannabis industry is significant, as we saw with the popularity of this fund on launch. We’re pleased to be able to offer more investors access to this industry.“Our clients value diversification. Medical cannabis is a volatile industry and our Cannabis Care CopyPortfolio allows investors to diversify their exposure to the sector.” The CopyPortfolio carries a minimum investment level of $5,000, and sits alongside other market-themed CopyPortfolios available on the eToro platform, including CopyPortfolios for those wanting exposure to banks, big tech, cryptoassets, gaming companies, and genome engineering technology.

urn:contentItem:5MHC-BBF1-F05M-K191-00000-00Investors peer into the crystal ball for a look at 20172016-12-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:48ZLexisNexisInvestors peer into the crystal ball for a look at 2017Cromwell Schubarth

As 2016 drew to a close, Silicon Valley venture investors made some predictions of what they think the new year will bring. Here are some interesting forecasts:

IPO market picks up
"I think we will see significant uptick in 2017 of IPOs for venture-backed technology companies. There are more great private tech companies with scale (revenues of between $50 million and $100 million or more), rapid growth and greater teams than we have ever had. There is also plenty of capital available for exits - both M&A and IPOs. The big tech companies have unprecedented cash hoards. Money managers have a keen interest in IPOs as a source of 'alpha" in their portfolios.'" - Sandy Miller, Institutional Venture Partners

AI-buying market accelerates
"With large incumbents continuing to recognize how artificial intelligence and machine learning will affect their business, the M&A market for AI startups will continue to expand. Unlike prior years, most of the buyers will be non-tech companies aiming to build some capability in-house to leverage emerging technologies." - Omar El-Ayat, Crosslink Capital

Letting fintech loose
"Both incumbent financial institutions and the new fintech competitors and innovators will thrive due to the lessening of the regulatory burden. There will also be increased mass adoption of security for fintech and all financial services companies." - David Blumberg, Blumberg Capital

Click here to get the free daily TechFlash Silicon Valley newsletter.

Digitizing the assembly line
"Manufacturing in the U.S. was at the core of the industrial revolution, yet the digital revolution of this century has lent minimal improvements to this space. Cloud computing, mobile enablement, and collaborative work online have been unheard of in much of the manufacturing space. Productivity gains from these technologies have been astronomical in the professional and business worlds; 2017 will be the year when many of these technologies impact the industrial design and manufacturing spaces. In addition, technologies such as augmented reality and artificial intelligence, which have struggled to find tangible use cases in the consumer space, stand to see the greatest acceptance rates in manufacturing." - Dayna Grayson, New Enterprise Associates

Where's that return on AI spending?
"Companies will begin looking for demonstrable value and ROI proof points from AI technologies. While funding for AI-related startups keeps increasing - in the last five years alone, investments in AI have grown tenfold from $94 million in 2011 to more than $1 billion in 2016 - we've seen few real commercial applications surface. Most often these technologies are piloted by innovation teams or an R&D department. 2017 will be the tipping point when companies start questioning their investments and AI will have to grow up." - Stuart Frankel, Battery Ventures

Many more acquihires
"The acquihire trend will amplify in the coming year as strong talent continues to prove hard to find." - Greg Becker, Silicon Valley Bank

urn:contentItem:52R9-F401-F0J6-S3GK-00000-00Investors play on as Vietnam founders2011-04-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:47ZLexisNexisEQUITIESInvestors play on as Vietnam foundersLawrence White Lawrence White Lawrence White

After the default of one of its biggest state-owned companies in December, the country's latest round of problems began: ratings downgrades, rising inflation and an 8.5% devaluation. Yet some investors are optimistic. They think its markets are cheap, and are waiting on a new wave of IPOs. Lawrence White reports

AT THE END of 2010 and the beginning of this year, one negative story after another about Vietnam hit the headlines of the local and international media. On December 20, indebted state-owned shipbuilder Vinashin missed a $60 million principal payment to its creditors, revealing a long-suspected funding problem at the company. Three days later Standard & Poor's followed Moody's and Fitch Ratings in cutting the country's long-term credit rating by one notch, having warned on December 13 that Vinashin's woes might affect the creditworthiness of some banks. Then, as fears about inflation developed, the government announced on February 11 that it was devaluing the dong by 8.5% against the US dollar. The IMF welcomed the move as necessary to close the gap between the official and black-market exchange rates but the market responded with unintended grim humour by immediately pushing the unofficial rate higher still. While the official rate moved from D18,932 to the dollar to D20,693, within five days the &unofficial rate had climbed to D21,900.

As the Vinashin debacle developed, coverage in the local &media exposed more problems at the company. The search for the individuals responsible had begun in August 2010 with the arrest of the chairman, Pham Thanh Binh. The ministry of public security announced in mid-February that it was investigating two former officials at the company - former director of Vinashin Finance Company Ho Ngoc Tung and his deputy, Trinh Thi Hau - for deliberate violation of state economic regulations that allegedly lost the company more than $3 million. On February 24 Vietnam cancelled a $9.8 billion project between Vinashin and Malaysia's Lion Group. As the bad news accumulated, murky details began to emerge. There were reports of further arrests and of officials in a Vinashin investment project buying mothballed, toxic, 50-year old equipment from a South Korean power plant.

Investors, regulators and the government are all worried by these revelations. The question they are all asking is "how deep does the rot go?" Vietnam's risk profile has been seriously affected, with the ratings agencies downgrading it and credit default swaps on the country's sovereign debt widening by about 80 basis points to 300bp by January 17 and to over 400bp by mid-February.

Calm optimists

Yet Vietnam's robust optimists are remaining calm. "The CDS has gone over 400bp," says Nikhil Singh, equities head at Indochina Capital, "but it's skewed because it's one of the few ways investors can hedge Vietnam risk. And you're still talking about a price level that's less than half what you'd pay to insure against Greece or Ireland."

Spending a week talking to bank executives, fund managers, individual investors and market authorities in Vietnam throws up a curious feeling of paradox. Almost everyone Euromoney spoke to talked with dismay or at best cheerful pessimism about the country's short-term economic problems but also universally recommended the country as a destination for investment.

It is easy to assume that this is akin to the desperation of a man who has only ice to sell suddenly finding himself transported to the Arctic. However, the situation is more complex. With a young, entrepreneurial population, a developing portfolio of good companies and a favourable geographical position for regional trade, Vietnam has developed into a country with excellent prospects. The problem is that the curses of hot money, governmental policy tinkering and global economic problems have conspired to make the country's stock index charts for the past 10 years resemble the peaks and troughs of a particularly dramatic mountain range. This is one of Asia's most exciting, but most risky, investment destinations.

Bad is good

When in November 2009 Euromoney visited the offices of Indochina Capital, one of the more prominent overseas investment firms active in Vietnam's southern financial hub, Ho Chi Minh City, the mood was of post-disaster clean-up. Interim manager of the equities division Beat Schuerch had been retained to deal with the fallout from the closure of the firm's Vietnam equities fund, following the crash that began in 2007 and continued for the next 18 months, wiping out all the gains from what had been Asia's best-performing equity index. Returning to the same firm in February this year, Euromoney is greeted by new equities head Nikhil Singh, who says the very fact that Vietnam has had a bad run lately makes this a good time to invest.

He says: "I've just come out of a meeting with [listed, majority state-owned dairy company] Vinamilk, who are growing at something like 25% a year and are valued at a price/earnings ratio of just nine. There are good companies here with low market penetration and plenty of room to grow, if you look beyond the negative headlines."

Grabbing a flipchart used for presentations to investors, &Singh makes his case. He cites four main attractions for investing in Vietnam. Valuations are at a four-year low, with an average P/E ratio of 43 in 2007 down to about 11; the drive to equitize (privatize) leading state-owned companies is set to resume; quotas on foreign ownership of companies and sectors are being filled up; and the best companies are growing strongly despite the economic headwinds.

The quotas, designed to make sure foreign investors cannot hold majority stakes in either specific companies or whole sectors, are part of the reason why investing in Vietnam holds practical difficulties aside from any concerns about macroeconomic or corporate governance issues. When Euromoney wrote about Vinamilk's listing in an April 2006 article presciently titled "Vietnam's stock market: buckle up and proceed with caution", it was noted that this IPO single-handedly almost doubled the market capitalization of the Ho Chi Minh stock exchange. The market is thin, and quotas for many of the best companies are almost full and seldom traded, meaning that the market is somewhat illiquid and prone to sudden lurches upwards and downwards. Furthermore, as reported in last month's issue, the effect of the opening of two Vietnam-focused offshore exchange-traded funds has been to drive up dramatically the valuations of the large-cap firms that these ETFs track.

"There are good companies here with low market penetration and plenty of room to grow, if you look beyond the negative headlines"Nikhil Singh, Indochina Capital
Better prices

"Vietnam's now very attractive in terms of pricing, compared with 2007 when the [Ho Chi Minh] index was around 1,200," says Pham Ngoc Bich, head of research and investment advisory at local securities firm SSI. "Now it is down at 500, P/E ratios are around 10. If you look at the market-cap weighted average, it's around 20 times because the big-cap stocks have rocketed, but if you remove those five to 10 largest stocks, this is one of the cheapest markets in the region."

Part of the problem with Vietnam has always been its shallow markets. The lack of attractive listed stocks is made worse by the speculative approach to stock trading that local retail investors take. Gold and real estate are seen as long-term investments and equities as a way to make quick money when the markets boom. Add to this mix the tendency for foreign capital to wash in and out of the country in large, fast-moving waves and you have the recipe for a volatile market in which it is hard to build a long-term, diversified portfolio. Vietnam needs more companies to list.

Vinashin's default highlighted the problems that afflict the least efficient of Vietnam's state-owned enterprises. Market participants hope its troubles will work in reverse and encourage the speedy resumption of the programme to list SOEs that was put on hold during the crisis.

"There are over 1,000 SOEs," says SSI's Pham Ngoc Bich, "and the only long-term solution to the issue of their inefficiency is to privatize. That process slowed down over the past two years; everyone's hoping it will resume."

Indochina Capital identifies at least 60 SOEs with approved privatization plans, including crown jewels such as the bank BIDV, Vietnam Airlines, and tourism firms Hanoitourist and Saigontourist. The question is whether or not the government will push through these listings soon, given the uncertain macro&economic climate.

Strategic plan

"We've completed our strategic plan for the next five years," says Linh H Nguyen, director in the strategy and international cooperation department at Hanoi Stock Exchange, "which includes raising our market capitalization to 20% of GDP. But that might be tough given the sluggish economy. Once the new securities law comes into effect in July, that will improve listing requirements in such areas as corporate governance and disclosure, which should lead to more listings of a higher quality."

It might be difficult to convince investors to support the partial listing of even the most solid-seeming state-owned companies. Vinashin is seen as an outlier, unusually poorly managed and unlucky to see its core business of shipbuilding hammered as the price of new ships crashed in the crisis. The real issue, says VinaCapital's head of investment, Andy Ho, is that the company's recent failings have made potential investors question the quality of management at other SOEs.

"Most big businesses are in some way conglomerates," Ho says. "Consider Samsung, LG, most of the big tech groups... diversification from your core business is not a problem if you have the resources and skill to manage it. Vietnam's SOEs need to work out how better to train and incentivize managers."

Until then, says Ho, investors are right to be cautious.
