urn:contentItem:533K-MY51-F0J6-S3HY-00000-00Investors play on as Vietnam founders2011-04-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:48ZLexisNexisEQUITIESInvestors play on as Vietnam foundersLawrence White Lawrence White Lawrence White

After the default of one of its biggest state-owned companies in December, the country's latest round of problems began: ratings downgrades, rising inflation and an 8.5% devaluation. Yet some investors are optimistic. They think its markets are cheap, and are waiting on a new wave of IPOs. Lawrence White reports

AT THE END of 2010 and the beginning of this year, one negative story after another about Vietnam hit the headlines of the local and international media. On December 20, indebted state-owned shipbuilder Vinashin missed a $60 million principal payment to its creditors, revealing a long-suspected funding problem at the company. Three days later Standard & Poor's followed Moody's and Fitch Ratings in cutting the country's long-term credit rating by one notch, having warned on December 13 that Vinashin's woes might affect the creditworthiness of some banks. Then, as fears about inflation developed, the government announced on February 11 that it was devaluing the dong by 8.5% against the US dollar. The IMF welcomed the move as necessary to close the gap between the official and black-market exchange rates but the market responded with unintended grim humour by immediately pushing the unofficial rate higher still. While the official rate moved from D18,932 to the dollar to D20,693, within five days the ­unofficial rate had climbed to D21,900.

As the Vinashin debacle developed, coverage in the local ­media exposed more problems at the company. The search for the individuals responsible had begun in August 2010 with the arrest of the chairman, Pham Thanh Binh. The ministry of public security announced in mid-February that it was investigating two former officials at the company - former director of Vinashin Finance Company Ho Ngoc Tung and his deputy, Trinh Thi Hau - for deliberate violation of state economic regulations that allegedly lost the company more than $3 million. On February 24 Vietnam cancelled a $9.8 billion project between Vinashin and Malaysia's Lion Group. As the bad news accumulated, murky details began to emerge. There were reports of further arrests and of officials in a Vinashin investment project buying mothballed, toxic, 50-year old equipment from a South Korean power plant.

Investors, regulators and the government are all worried by these revelations. The question they are all asking is "how deep does the rot go?" Vietnam's risk profile has been seriously affected, with the ratings agencies downgrading it and credit default swaps on the country's sovereign debt widening by about 80 basis points to 300bp by January 17 and to over 400bp by mid-February.

Calm optimists

Yet Vietnam's robust optimists are remaining calm. "The CDS has gone over 400bp," says Nikhil Singh, equities head at Indochina Capital, "but it's skewed because it's one of the few ways investors can hedge Vietnam risk. And you're still talking about a price level that's less than half what you'd pay to insure against Greece or Ireland."

Spending a week talking to bank executives, fund managers, individual investors and market authorities in Vietnam throws up a curious feeling of paradox. Almost everyone Euromoney spoke to talked with dismay or at best cheerful pessimism about the country's short-term economic problems but also universally recommended the country as a destination for investment.

It is easy to assume that this is akin to the desperation of a man who has only ice to sell suddenly finding himself transported to the Arctic. However, the situation is more complex. With a young, entrepreneurial population, a developing portfolio of good companies and a favourable geographical position for regional trade, Vietnam has developed into a country with excellent prospects. The problem is that the curses of hot money, governmental policy tinkering and global economic problems have conspired to make the country's stock index charts for the past 10 years resemble the peaks and troughs of a particularly dramatic mountain range. This is one of Asia's most exciting, but most risky, investment destinations.

Bad is good

When in November 2009 Euromoney visited the offices of Indochina Capital, one of the more prominent overseas investment firms active in Vietnam's southern financial hub, Ho Chi Minh City, the mood was of post-disaster clean-up. Interim manager of the equities division Beat Schuerch had been retained to deal with the fallout from the closure of the firm's Vietnam equities fund, following the crash that began in 2007 and continued for the next 18 months, wiping out all the gains from what had been Asia's best-performing equity index. Returning to the same firm in February this year, Euromoney is greeted by new equities head Nikhil Singh, who says the very fact that Vietnam has had a bad run lately makes this a good time to invest.

He says: "I've just come out of a meeting with [listed, majority state-owned dairy company] Vinamilk, who are growing at something like 25% a year and are valued at a price/earnings ratio of just nine. There are good companies here with low market penetration and plenty of room to grow, if you look beyond the negative headlines."

Grabbing a flipchart used for presentations to investors, ­Singh makes his case. He cites four main attractions for investing in Vietnam. Valuations are at a four-year low, with an average P/E ratio of 43 in 2007 down to about 11; the drive to equitize (privatize) leading state-owned companies is set to resume; quotas on foreign ownership of companies and sectors are being filled up; and the best companies are growing strongly despite the economic headwinds.

The quotas, designed to make sure foreign investors cannot hold majority stakes in either specific companies or whole sectors, are part of the reason why investing in Vietnam holds practical difficulties aside from any concerns about macroeconomic or corporate governance issues. When Euromoney wrote about Vinamilk's listing in an April 2006 article presciently titled "Vietnam's stock market: buckle up and proceed with caution", it was noted that this IPO single-handedly almost doubled the market capitalization of the Ho Chi Minh stock exchange. The market is thin, and quotas for many of the best companies are almost full and seldom traded, meaning that the market is somewhat illiquid and prone to sudden lurches upwards and downwards. Furthermore, as reported in last month's issue, the effect of the opening of two Vietnam-focused offshore exchange-traded funds has been to drive up dramatically the valuations of the large-cap firms that these ETFs track.

"There are good companies here with low market penetration and plenty of room to grow, if you look beyond the negative headlines"Nikhil Singh, Indochina Capital
Better prices

"Vietnam's now very attractive in terms of pricing, compared with 2007 when the [Ho Chi Minh] index was around 1,200," says Pham Ngoc Bich, head of research and investment advisory at local securities firm SSI. "Now it is down at 500, P/E ratios are around 10. If you look at the market-cap weighted average, it's around 20 times because the big-cap stocks have rocketed, but if you remove those five to 10 largest stocks, this is one of the cheapest markets in the region."

Part of the problem with Vietnam has always been its shallow markets. The lack of attractive listed stocks is made worse by the speculative approach to stock trading that local retail investors take. Gold and real estate are seen as long-term investments and equities as a way to make quick money when the markets boom. Add to this mix the tendency for foreign capital to wash in and out of the country in large, fast-moving waves and you have the recipe for a volatile market in which it is hard to build a long-term, diversified portfolio. Vietnam needs more companies to list.

Vinashin's default highlighted the problems that afflict the least efficient of Vietnam's state-owned enterprises. Market participants hope its troubles will work in reverse and encourage the speedy resumption of the programme to list SOEs that was put on hold during the crisis.

"There are over 1,000 SOEs," says SSI's Pham Ngoc Bich, "and the only long-term solution to the issue of their inefficiency is to privatize. That process slowed down over the past two years; everyone's hoping it will resume."

Indochina Capital identifies at least 60 SOEs with approved privatization plans, including crown jewels such as the bank BIDV, Vietnam Airlines, and tourism firms Hanoitourist and Saigontourist. The question is whether or not the government will push through these listings soon, given the uncertain macro­economic climate.

Strategic plan

"We've completed our strategic plan for the next five years," says Linh H Nguyen, director in the strategy and international cooperation department at Hanoi Stock Exchange, "which includes raising our market capitalization to 20% of GDP. But that might be tough given the sluggish economy. Once the new securities law comes into effect in July, that will improve listing requirements in such areas as corporate governance and disclosure, which should lead to more listings of a higher quality."

It might be difficult to convince investors to support the partial listing of even the most solid-seeming state-owned companies. Vinashin is seen as an outlier, unusually poorly managed and unlucky to see its core business of shipbuilding hammered as the price of new ships crashed in the crisis. The real issue, says VinaCapital's head of investment, Andy Ho, is that the company's recent failings have made potential investors question the quality of management at other SOEs.

"Most big businesses are in some way conglomerates," Ho says. "Consider Samsung, LG, most of the big tech groups... diversification from your core business is not a problem if you have the resources and skill to manage it. Vietnam's SOEs need to work out how better to train and incentivize managers."

Until then, says Ho, investors are right to be cautious.

New York (CNN Business)It was a wild day on Wall Street. The Nasdaq Composite It was the worst day for stocks since June. Stocks erased all their gains after a huge bout of exuberance Wednesday, when the S&P 500 (SPX) — the broadest measure of Wall Street — and the Nasdaq hit yet another record high. The Nasdaq had also climbed above 12,000 points for the first time in history Wednesday. But it didn't stick. Thursday was the Nasdaq's largest one-day decline from a record high in its history, according to Bespoke Investment Group. All three major indexes finished the day sharply lower. The Nasdaq closed down nearly 5%, and the S&P fell 3.5%, while the Dow finished 2.8%, or 808 points, lower. So, what happened? For one, the the other two major stock indexes — the Dow (INDU) and the S&P 500 (SPX) — for months. The rally has been going on for long enough that investors are now taking profit. Even so, the Nasdaq remains up nearly 28% in 2020, still far outpacing its counterparts. The Dow, which only recently turned positive for the year, is back in the red. "Although there is no single driver for the weakness, it seems as if investors all of a sudden realized how overbought stocks are and sold. Someone yelled fire in a crowded theater and everyone left at once," said Ryan Detrick, chief market strategist for LPL Financial, in emailed comments. But there are also technical reasons for Thursday's decline: As US-China relations sour, investors are moving money out of tech, which could get hit the hardest from a potential increase in tariffs. "The Nasdaq is getting hit hard with the continued rotation into cyclicals and expectations big-tech will ultimately pay the cost to a further deterioration with US-Chinese relations," said Ed Moya, senior market analyst at Oanda. Stocks in cyclical sectors are expected to perform better as the economy is recovering. The Big Tech companies such as Amazon (AMZN), Google (GOOGL) and Microsoft (MSFT), all of which are part of the Nasdaq, have become the safe-haven investment of the summer. But investors have beginning to wonder when the rally will run out of steam, either because of increased regulation or because the economy as a whole picks up enough to void the need for safety picks altogether. "It's a bit of a wake-up call, which isn't the worst thing in the world. Markets go up and down," JJ Kinahan, chief market strategist at TD Ameritrade, told CNN Business. Tech stocks were among Thursday's worst performers. Given the summer rally, it's "perfectly normal," to see tech stocks readjusting a bit, Detrick said. But even investors who are still faithful to their safe tech holdings have reason to be a little concerned: Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious diseases, told CNN Thursday that a Covid-19 vaccine by October remained "unlikely," though it was possible. Making matters worse, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said late Wednesday that "the cooperative spirit we had in March and April" on Capitol Hill has "dissipated as we move closer and closer to the election." This doesn't bode well for Congress agreeing on another stimulus bill, which the market has been hoping for.

urn:contentItem:5S2G-S3W1-F0GS-H3VV-00000-00Investors rush to reposition against terrible trio2018-03-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:48ZLexisNexisEQUITY,CAPITAL,MARKETS,FACEBOOK,GOOGLE,FEDERAL,RESERVE,JEROME,JAY,POWELL,RATE,HIKEInvestors rush to reposition against terrible trioCostas Mourselas

Equity market volatility in the US spiked this week as investors scrambled to position for emerging risks, including impending tech regulation, an escalating trade war and rate hike worries.

On Monday, Facebook led a tech and data company sell-off, with investors concerned about a regulatory crackdown in response to data harvesting by political big data consultancy Cambridge Analytica. As a Federal Reserve meeting loomed, talk of tariffs between the US, the European Union and China also escalated during the week, helping drive markets lower on Thursday.

The Vix, an equity volatility gauge based on the S&P 500, rose from 15 last Friday to 23 on Thursday, a sharp increase.

On Wednesday, new Fed chair Jerome Powell raised the Federal Funds rate by 25bp, while indicating that the Fed could raise rates three times in 2019 and twice in 2020.

"We think the Fed meeting had quite a hawkish flavour to be honest," said Antoine Porcheret, equity derivatives strategist at BNP Paribas in London.

Reaction to the meeting was mixed, both from the strategists that spoke to GlobalCapital, and in equity markets themselves.

The Dow Jones industrial average initially went up after the announcement, but then erased any gains, opening 1.1% lower the next day. The S&P 500 opened 0.8% lower from close on Thursday, and was down a further 0.8% at 7pm UK time. The dollar weakened against the euro and pound in the immediate aftermath of the meeting, but then regained those losses the next day. Strategists were tracking the currency pairs as a more expensive currency follows higher rates, all else being equal.

Joseph LaVorgna, chief economist for the Americas at Natixis, said that the the escalating trade war between the US and other countries, as well as the big tech selloff, were factors in equity weakness, but not the biggest market concern.

"The main factor behind weaker equity prices has been the Fed, and the concern that higher interest rates and the removal of liquidity will have potentially profound negative implications for GDP growth," he added.

Hervé Guyon, equity derivatives flow strategies and solutions Europe at Société Générale in London, took the opposite view, saying that the meeting was actually more dovish than had been priced in by the market. He noted that the dollar traded lower immediately after the meeting.

"The market is not observing any clear signs of accelerating inflation, so the implication is that the Fed doesn't think it's behind the curve with rate hikes," he said.

Many GlobalCapital sources were generally careful not to attribute equity market weakness on Thursday to any one factor, noting that reverberations from the suffering tech sector and more talk of tariffs from US president Donald Trump had all contributed to the jitters.Thumbs down

The news that Cambridge Analytica, a big data political consultancy, may have harvested data from millions of Facebook profiles to support political efforts attracted widespread public criticism and sparked fresh calls for reigning in and regulating big tech companies this week. Facebook's share price fell by more than 10% since last Friday's close, as investors considered the implications for a tech sector that has delivered incredible returns over the past two years.

Guyon noted that Facebook and other tech companies could also face harsher taxes in Europe, as the European Commission this week reveals a 3% tax for the sector.

"There is also clearly regulation to come regarding the responsibility of tech companies to protect user data, which will increase costs," he said. "However, they still have huge potential, especially since they are well positioned to take advantage of developments in AI."

Both Porcheret and Guyon noted that now would be a good time for derivatives players to sell the correlation between big tech companies like Google, Amazon and Facebook.

"Over the past year they [big tech companies] have been very correlated, but new regulations and taxes would likely affect these companies differently," said Porcheret.

Investors can take this exposure by selling a correlation swap, making a return if realised correlation is below a specific strike price. They can also buy volatility on single names like Facebook, while selling volatility on a basket or index that encompasses the whole sector.

One equity analyst told GlobalCapital on Tuesday that a new "regulatory" premium was being priced into big tech He added that he had been "cautious" on technology stocks for the last six months for this reason.

"The market will be much more on our side on this risk," he added.Trump Trade

Fears about a full-blown trade war between the US, the EU and China also severely spooked markets this week. Investors scrambled for ways to gain upside or hedge their positions as the situation developed.

President Trump on Thursday announced tariff action against China for intellectual property violations.

Guyon told GlobalCapital that Société Générale has designed an index allowing investors to short a global basket of stocks likely to be affected by the trade war, adding that it had received significant interest from portfolio managers.

"It includes names from the metal and mining sectors and auto industries," he added.

Porcheret was sceptical about creating broader exposure to the trade war, telling GlobalCapital that academic research concluded that there were no "serious comparisons to be made historically" to the situation, making it difficult to position correctly.

"There is of course a consensus that tariffs will be bad for economic growth and the free flow of capital, but any conclusions should focus on the micro level impact, rather than the macro level," he added.

urn:contentItem:5YHC-JJT1-JDJN-60KX-00000-00Investors seeking positive opportunities amid coronavirus gloom2020-03-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:47ZLexisNexisInvestors seeking positive opportunities amid coronavirus gloomBaset Asaba

Investors are now actively seeking 'new world' sectors and companies as the world readjusts to life with coronavirus and looks ahead to an economic recovery.

The assessment from Nigel Green, the chief executive and founder of deVere Group, one of the world's largest independent financial advisory organizations with operations in 100 countries, comes as global stock markets rallied on Tuesday.

Mr Green notes: "Every economic downturn creates a new normal. The one being triggered by the coronavirus pandemic will be the same.

"The Covid-19 impact has hit firms across the world – there's been immense international disruption - with many sectors experiencing major issues of supply, demand, or both.

"However there remain some sections of the economy which are benefitting from the coronavirus fallout."

He continues: "Sensibly, investors are now actively seeking these 'new world' sectors and companies in order to grow and protect their wealth.

"This is evidenced by the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite index which has done well, where other global indices have faltered.

"New industries will come into their own and, as ever, there will be winners and losers.  This will mean job losses in some sectors and huge - possibly unprecedented - job and investment opportunities in others."

Last week, in a media release, Nigel Green noted that a Covid-19 recession is likely "to fundamentally shift how we live, do business and invest."  He added that it could also be expected to "speed up the Fourth Revolution, which is fuelled by new technologies, such as Artificial Intelligence and mobile supercomputing."

Mr Green goes on to say: "Big tech is just one likely winner.  The likes of Apple, Facebook, Amazon, and Google's parent company Alphabet have immense cash reserves to continue, maybe even bolster, research and development and to sustain their business operations.

"This sector is also likely to face higher demand as social distancing, isolation and quarantine affect much of its existing and potential consumer base.

"Plus, recently heightened regulatory restrictions and political opposition to their expansion and growth of influence is likely to be scaled back considerably."

He adds: "For similar and other reasons, other sectors besides the Silicon Valley giants, are likely to continue to offer positives for investors.

"These include pharmaceutical and healthcare firms, delivery brands, supermarkets and manufacturers of electronic goods, such as fridges and freezers."

Nigel Green concludes: "Of course, there will be a recovery from the global economic impact of coronavirus.

"But the world has already changed as a result of it - and will do so more - and savvy investors are aware of this new normal and are already readjusting their portfolios accordingly.

"Times of immense tumult can be times of great ingenuity, promise and opportunity."

urn:contentItem:5SGV-Y081-JBG3-611R-00000-00Investors See Tech Stocks As a Refuge2018-06-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:48ZLexisNexisSection BColumn 0Business/Financial DeskPg. 4Investors See Tech Stocks As a RefugeBy STEPHEN GROCER

Investors have returned to the safety and growth of the biggest technology stocks.

Five big tech companies -- Apple, Amazon, Microsoft, Netflixand Nvidia -- closed at historic highs on Tuesday. Alibaba and Facebookhave done the same in recent days. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite has returned to record territory, up 8 percent since the end of April. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Dow Jones industrial average remain 4.3 percent and 6.8 percent off the records they set on Jan. 26.

The rally has come as the global economy shows signs of strain. Fears of a trade war have made investors anxious; emerging market stocks, bonds and currencies have all sold off; and economic data in some regions has softened in recent weeks.

''In an uncertain world with significant downside economic tail risks, technology has been seen to be, correctly, relatively stable,'' Peter Oppenheimer and Guillaume Jaisson, strategists at Goldman Sachs, wrote in a recent report.

Such economic uneasiness in the years since the financial crisis had caused investors to pour money into the sector. The likes of Facebook, Alphabet, Amazon and Apple have come to be viewed as having nearly unassailable revenue streams that could deliver growth in most economic conditions. With interest rates at historic lows and economic growth lackluster, investors have found that appealing.

''Investors have been well served by the current global dominance of American tech companies, and yet there is plenty of chatter about changing this winning approach,'' Nicholas Colas, co-founder of DataTrek Research, said in a recent note.

In March, some of the best-performing tech stocks began to struggle. Facebook's handling of user data in the Cambridge Analytica scandal contributed to a backlash against the size and reach of the biggest tech companies and raised concerns that regulators may soon crack down on these firms.

The pullback was a rare dip for a sector that had risen consistently for the past several years. Since stock markets in the United States bottomed out in March 2009, shares of Apple, Amazon, Nvidia, Microsoft and Alphabet have all gained more than 500 percent; Netflixis up 6,500 percent. The S.&P. 500 has risen about 300 percent over that period.

How long can the biggest tech stocks dominate the market? For a while, Mr. Oppenheimer and Mr. Jaisson said. They pointed out that earnings and sales growth, not a speculative increase in valuations, have driven the post-financial crisis run-up.

''Unlike the technology mania of the 1990s, most of this success can be explained by strong fundamentals, revenues and earnings rather than speculation about the future,'' Mr. Oppenheimer and Mr. Jaisson wrote.

urn:contentItem:60G3-3FC1-JCJY-G32S-00000-00Investors should buckle up for the US presidential race2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:47ZLexisNexisInvestors should buckle up for the US presidential raceJames Norrington

We knew they were coming. But only in August, when the Democrat ticket is finalised, can investors begin to second guess the impact of US elections. On Monday, polls showed that challenger Joe Biden's lead over Donald Trump had widened (RealClearPolitics' 'RCP Average' has Biden at +9 per cent), making his choice of running mate even more pertinent for asset markets.

One thing is certain: Mr Biden will be standing alongside a woman, and it's likely she'll have a minority ethnic background - with odds for former ambassador to the United Nations Susan Rice (7:2), California Representative Karen Bass (6:1) and Illinois Rep. and Iraq war veteran Tammy Duckworth (8:1) narrowing the gap on bookies' favourite, California senator Kamala Harris (evens), at the start of the week.

Given that 77-year-old Mr. Biden would be the oldest president in history, there is much conjecture that his deputy will have an expanded role. Although discussions around whether she'll be a left-winger don't necessarily focus on predilections to fiscal largesse - after $3 trillion in federal government stimulus (and a further $1.2 trillion under discussion) to support the economy through Covid-19, that horse has bolted - the approach to tax and regulation will be paramount.

Speaking at the Legg Mason Global asset management forum, Margaret Vitrano, large-cap equity portfolio manager at ClearBridge Investments, highlighted some estimates that reversing President Trump's cuts to corporation tax could shave 15 per cent off S&P 500 earnings, although such action would require legislative approval in the two congressional houses.

Republicans currently have a majority in the Senate and the Democrats control the House of Representatives, so the balance is finely poised. If Mr Biden is elected president, but the Republicans retain control of the upper house in Congress, then the scope for tax cuts is greatly reduced.

Such an outcome would possibly be the most market positive, says Clearbridge investment strategist Jeffrey Schulze: "A Biden win and a Republican Senate could be a bullish short-term event. The outlook would improve for international trade, possibly with China but definitely with Europe, and the risk of higher taxes would be off the table."

In any case, even if there was a clean sweep for the Democrats, the positive case for Mr Schulze is that "Biden may not pull the lever on tax rises as he'd need to prioritise recovery and economic growth".

The most compelling reason not to raise taxes, in his view, are estimates that taking corporation tax back up to 28 per cent would only raise $70-$130bn a year for the US Treasury anyway - "a drop in the bucket" compared to the $4trn budget deficit forecast this year - so the benefits are marginal.

Overall, however, Mr Schulze is cautious should the 50:50 chance of a Democrat sweep come to pass. He would not be surprised to see Democrats push for a partial reversal of corporation tax cuts (perhaps taking them back to 25 per cent, if not the full 28 per cent), albeit these would be pushed back a year or so and he would expect the S&P 500 to take a 5-10 per cent haircut.

Perhaps a greater threat of a strong Democrat mandate is in regulation. Although she has dropped back to 16-1 to be running mate, Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren is a long-time advocate of challenging the monopolistic practices of big tech firms.

Big Tech in Washington

This week, the chief executives of Apple (US:AAPL), Amazon (US:AMZN), Google's parent Alphabet (US:GOOGL) and Facebook (US:FB.) are standing in front of Congress being questioned on their competitive practices. The prospect of antitrust legislation casts a shadow over their future.

Investors will be all too aware that a high proportion of profits growth for the S&P 500 has been concentrated in the tech behemoths and, with Q2 2020 results being reported by Facebook, Alphabet and Amazon this week, there should be another reminder of their importance.

Pharma and healthcare

Pharmaceutical and healthcare companies have also been subject to political risk. Ever since Hillary Clinton's drug price tweets in 2016, they have been "walking around with a target on their back" says Ms Vitrano. There is a recognition, however, that the Covid-19 crisis has shown the value of a strong research and manufacturing base in the country and possibly these companies could find the Democrats a more benign prospect than had they won four years ago.

When Joe Biden won the Democrat nomination from Bernie Sanders, MediCare4All - a state backed health funding scheme with no need for private insurance - was taken off the table as a policy option. Mr Biden prefers gradual evolution of the old Obamacare, so the risk to the industry has subsided significantly.

MediCare4All was of greatest threat to insurance-funded hospital and care-home models, and in 2017 drugs were only around 14 per cent of the US healthcare market. That said, the industry will still benefit from drug pricing slipping down the political agenda as policymakers focus on dealing with Covid-19.

If anything, the pandemic is a chance for drug manufacturers to improve their public relations and Geoffrey Hsu, manager of The Biotechnology Growth Trust (BIOG), said in his fund's annual presentation that companies he'd spoken with intended to generously price products that could help fight Covid-19.

President Trump's answer to drug price inflation was to remove red tape in the approval process and this decision has helped to bring products to market quickly and keep the lid on prices. Unforgettably, Mr Trump's assertions about the science behind bleach as a cure for coronavirus earned strong ridicule - but his policies have helped to expedite what was already a strong pipeline of drugs.

Overall, Mr Hsu rates a Biden presidency with a split Congress as the most positive outcome for biotechnology and pharmaceutical companies. Since Bernie Sanders threw in the towel, arguably the industry's worst-case scenario of a Democratic clean sweep of presidency and both houses of congress should no longer be viewed so negatively.

What this view doesn't allow for is a left-wing Vice President, however. No doubt Republican strategists will focus on Mr Biden's age and who might provide the real energy and drive should the Democrats win. Medicare4All is supported by Kamala Harris, Karen Bass and Elizabeth Warren, so future impetus to the policy can't be ruled out.

Led by a man who will be turning eighty by the mid-terms, it isn't unreasonable to expect that a Vice President would call significant shots. It's not inconceivable he could die of natural causes in office. Certainly, we could expect that his vice would be groomed to run after one term and that is where candidates more from the Sanders wing of the Democrat party could pose the threat of greater regulation to some industries, if they also enjoyed control of Congress.

Battle over health and economic narratives to dominate election run-in

More immediately, the confusing aspect for investors will be cutting through the noise as mudslinging commences in what will be a brutally fought campaign. While this week's congressional hearings into big tech are primarily about competition, it won't be lost on Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg how damaging any repeat of the Cambridge Analytica scandal - the small research firm that in 2018 was found to have breached Facebook user security to harvest data for political advertisers - would be to his company.

Reporting in traditional media is partisan too, which could have the consequence of making people less bold about going out and partaking in normal activities - in turn weighing on economic recovery. Initial positive data after states exited lockdown has been dampened; notably the US weekly unemployment claims have once again risen above 1.4m and 32m people were collecting jobless benefits at the start of July.

As for the virus, cases and deaths are rising but the death rate per confirmed case is dramatically lower in California, Texas and Florida than it was in New York. The loss of life is still tragic but as better treatment methods are being practiced and older people are practising social distancing more effectively, the burden on health services is more manageable.

That's not to be flippant about a 7-day rolling average death rate that nationally has almost doubled in three weeks and now runs at over 900 per day, but the fear of being overwhelmed has been replaced with an impassioned debate over the trade-off between safety and the need to get the economy up and running again.

The situation is not the same as in March, says John Bellows, fixed income portfolio manager at Western Asset, when the fear was not knowing whether the virus could be contained or managed. Along with that uncertainty factor he puts the velocity of markets selling off earlier in the year down to the US Treasury market breaking down, but gives the Federal Reserve credit for stepping in and safeguarding the financial system.

The V-shaped economic recovery that started in April has been stopped in its tracks and Mr Bellows sees a far more gradual recovery and higher unemployment as the US loses 5-6 per cent of economic activity. That won't come back overnight as the virus has made people more cautious.

In the meantime, however, the federal reserve is continuing to pump money into bond markets, and Mr Bellows does see an opportunity in investment grade credit. Spreads are still wider than a year ago and the fed is prepared to provide whatever bridging funding lines corporates need to get through the crisis, so a great-risk reward in quality corporate bonds is materialising.

Should spreads widen meaningfully, the Fed could double or triple its buying programme, as it is committed to taking the volatility out of credit markets. Given there is still material upside, investment grade corporate credit is a "very interesting asset class", in Mr Bellows' view.

This week the Federal Reserve open market committee is meeting to discuss next steps. Chair Jay Powell's signal that they aren't even thinking about raising rates was described by Mr Schulze as making his predecessors Ben Bernanke and Janet Yellen, who were famous exponents of monetary easing after the financial crisis, look like the infamously hawkish Paul Volcker.

Most likely, the Fed will continue to signal how dovish it is while hinting at future measures such as yield curve control - committing to buy up bonds of certain maturities to keep forward rates at target level, helping manage on the run and off the run liquidity.

Unfortunately, but all too predictably, the politicians aren't as committed as the Fed to pouring oil on troubled water and wrangling over the latest $1.2 trillion fiscal boost has weighed on the value of the US dollar. The hold-up has been due, in part, to concerns among Republicans that some schemes require better monitoring.

It is also unhelpful, albeit inevitable, that the debate around how to re-open the economy is so politicised and toxic. This is partly driven by the genuine need to balance saving lives with livelihoods, but it is a shame that sensible dialogue on this tragic real-world trade off takes a back seat to ideology for several leading actors in this election race.

urn:contentItem:60GF-PRP1-JCBW-N3W5-00000-00Investors should buckle up for the US presidential race;Democrat nominations could pose a risk to US shares2020-07-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:48ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10,11Investors should buckle up for the US presidential raceDemocrat nominations could pose a risk to US sharesJAMES NORRINGTON

We knew they were coming. But only in August, when the Democrat ticket is finalised, can investors start to second guess the impact of US elections. On Monday, polls showed that challenger Joe Biden's lead over Donald Trump had widened (RealClearPolitics' 'RCP Average' has Biden at +9 per cent), making his choice of running mate even more pertinent for asset markets.

One thing is certain: Mr Biden will be standing alongside a woman, and it's likely she'll have a minority ethnic background - with odds for former ambassador to the United Nations Susan Rice (7:2), California representative Karen Bass (6:1) and Illinois representative and Iraq war veteran Tammy Duckworth (8:1) narrowing the gap on bookies' favourite, California senator Kamala Harris (evens), at the start of the week.

Given that 77-year-old Mr Biden would be the oldest president in history, there is much conjecture that his deputy will have an expanded role. Although discussions around whether she'll be a left-winger don't necessarily focus on predilections to fiscal largesse - after $3 trillion in federal government stimulus (and a further $1.2 trillion under discussion) to support the economy through Covid-19, that horse has bolted - the approach to tax and regulation will be paramount.

Speaking at the Legg Mason Global asset management forum, Margaret Vitrano, large-cap equity portfolio manager at ClearBridge Investments, highlighted some estimates that reversing President Trump's cuts to corporation tax could shave 15 per cent off S&P 500 earnings, although such action would require legislative approval in the two congressional houses.

Republicans currently have a majority in the Senate and the Democrats control the House of Representatives, so the balance is finely poised. If Mr Biden is elected president, but the Republicans retain control of the upper house in Congress, then the scope for tax cuts is greatly reduced.

Such an outcome would possibly be the most marketpositive, says Clearbridge investment strategist Jeffrey Schulze: "A Biden win and a Republican Senate could be a bullish short-term event. The outlook would improve for international trade, possibly with China, but definitely with Europe, and the risk of higher taxes would be off the table."

In any case, even if there was a clean sweep for the Democrats, the positive case for Mr Schulze is that "Biden may not pull the lever on tax rises as he'd need to prioritise recovery and economic growth".

The most compelling reason not to raise taxes, in his view, are estimates that taking corporation tax back up to 28 per cent would only raise $70bn-$130bn a year for the US Treasury anyway - "a drop in the bucket" compared with the $4 trillion budget deficit forecast this year - so the benefits are marginal.

Overall, however, Mr Schulze is cautious should the 50:50 chance of a Democrat sweep come to pass. He would not be surprised to see Democrats push for a partial reversal of corporation tax cuts (perhaps taking them back to 25 per cent, if not the full 28 per cent), albeit these would be pushed back a year or so and he would expect the S&P 500 to take a 5-10 per cent haircut.

Perhaps a greater threat of a strong Democrat mandate is in regulation. Although she has dropped back to 16-1 to be running mate, Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren is a long-time advocate of challenging the monopolistic practices of big tech companies.

Big Tech in Washington This week, the chief executives of Apple (US:AAPL), Amazon (US:AMZN), Google's parent Alphabet (US:GOOGL) and Facebook (US:FB.) are standing in front of Congress being questioned on their competitive practices. The prospect of antitrust legislation casts a shadow over their future.

Investors will be all too aware that a high proportion of profits growth for the S&P 500 has been concentrated in the tech behemoths and, with Q2 2020 results being reported by Facebook, Alphabet and Amazon this week, there should be another reminder of their importance.

Pharma and healthcare Pharmaceutical and healthcare companies have also been subject to political risk. Ever since Hillary Clinton's drug price tweets in 2016, they have been "walking around with a target on their back", says Ms Vitrano. There is a recognition, however, that the Covid-19 crisis has shown the value of a strong research and manufacturing base in the country and possibly these companies could find the Democrats a more benign prospect than had they won four years ago.

When Joe Biden won the Democrat nomination from Bernie Sanders, MediCare4All - a state-backed health funding scheme with no need for private insurance - was taken off the table as a policy option. Mr Biden prefers gradual evolution of the old Obamacare, so the risk to the industry has subsided significantly.

MediCare4All was of greatest threat to insurancefunded hospital and care-home models, and in 2017 drugs were only around 14 per cent of the US healthcare market. That said, the industry will still benefit from drug pricing slipping down the political agenda as policymakers focus on dealing with Covid-19.

If anything, the pandemic is a chance for drug manufacturers to improve their public relations and Geoffrey Hsu, manager of The Biotechnology Growth Trust (BIOG), said in his fund's annual presentation that companies he'd spoken with intended to generously price products that could help fight Covid-19.

President Trump's answer to drug price inflation was to remove red tape in the approval process and this decision has helped to bring products to market quickly and keep the lid on prices. Unforgettably, Mr Trump's assertions about the science behind bleach as a cure for coronavirus earned strong ridicule - but his policies have helped to expedite what was already a strong pipeline of drugs.

Overall, Mr Hsu rates a Biden presidency with a split Congress as the most positive outcome for biotechnology and pharmaceutical companies. Since Bernie Sanders threw in the towel, arguably the industry's worst-case scenario of a Democratic clean sweep of presidency and both houses of congress should no longer be viewed so negatively.

What this view doesn't allow for is a left-wing vicepresident, www.however.No doubt Republican strategists will focus on Mr Biden's age and who might provide the real energy and drive should the Democrats win. Medicare4All is supported by Kamala Harris, Karen Bass and Elizabeth Warren, so future impetus to the policy can't be ruled out.

Led by a man who will be turning 80 by the mid-terms, it isn't unreasonable to expect that a vice-president would call significant shots. It's not inconceivable he could die of natural causes in office. Certainly, we could expect that his vice would be groomed to run after one term and that is where candidates from the Sanders wing of the Democrat party could pose the threat of greater regulation to some industries, if they also enjoyed control of Congress.

Battle over health and economic narratives to dominate election run-in More immediately, the confusing aspect for investors will be cutting through the noise as mudslinging commences in what will be a brutally fought campaign. While this week's congressional hearings into big tech are primarily about competition, it won't be lost on Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg how damaging any repeat of the Cambridge Analytica scandal - the small research firm that in 2018 was found to have breached Facebook user security to harvest data for political advertisers - would be to his company.

Reporting in traditional media is partisan too, which could have the consequence of making people less bold about going out and partaking in normal activities - in turn weighing on economic recovery. Initial positive data after states exited lockdown has been dampened; notably the US weekly unemployment claims have once again risen above 1.4m and 32m people were collecting jobless benefits at the start of July.

As for the virus, cases and deaths are rising, but the death rate per confirmed case is dramatically lower in California, Texas and Florida than it was in New York. The loss of life is still tragic, but as better treatment methods are being practiced and older people are practising social distancing more effectively, the burden on health services is more manageable.

That's not to be flippant about a seven-day rolling average death rate that nationally has almost doubled in three weeks and now runs at over 900 per day, but the fear of being overwhelmed has been replaced with an impassioned debate over the trade-off between safety and the need to get the economy up and running again.

The situation is not the same as in March, says John Bellows, fixed-income portfolio manager at Western Asset, when the fear was not knowing whether the virus could be contained or managed. Along with that uncertainty factor he puts the velocity of markets selling off earlier in the year down to the US Treasury market breaking down, but gives the Federal Reserve credit for stepping in and safeguarding the financial system.

The V-shaped economic recovery that started in April has been stopped in its tracks and Mr Bellows sees a far more gradual recovery and higher unemployment as the US loses 5-6 per cent of economic activity. That won't come back overnight as the virus has made people more cautious.

In the meantime, however, the Federal Reserve is continuing to pump money into bond markets, and Mr Bellows does see an opportunity in investment-grade credit. Spreads are still wider than a year ago and the Fed is prepared to provide whatever bridging funding lines corporates need to get through the crisis, so a great risk/reward in quality corporate bonds is materialising.

Should spreads widen meaningfully, the Fed could double or triple its buying programme, as it is committed to taking the volatility out of credit markets. Given there is still material upside, investment-grade corporate credit is a "very interesting asset class", in Mr Bellows' view.

This week the Federal Reserve open market committee is meeting to discuss next steps. Chair Jay Powell's signal that they aren't even thinking about raising rates was described by Mr Schulze as making his predecessors Ben Bernanke and Janet Yellen, who were famous exponents of monetary easing after the financial crisis, look like the infamously hawkish Paul Volcker.

Most likely, the Fed will continue to signal how dovish it is while hinting at future measures such as yield curve control - committing to buy up bonds of certain maturities to keep forward rates at target level, helping manage on the run and off-the-run liquidity.

Unfortunately, but all too predictably, the politicians aren't as committed as the Fed to pouring oil on troubled water and wrangling over the latest $1.2 trillion fiscal boost has weighed on the value of the US dollar. The hold-up has been due, in part, to concerns among Republicans that some schemes require better monitoring.

It is also unhelpful, albeit inevitable, that the debate around how to reopen the economy is so politicised and toxic. This is partly driven by the genuine need to balance saving lives with livelihoods, but it is a shame that sensible dialogue on this tragic real-world trade-off takes a back seat to ideology for several leading actors in this election race.

urn:contentItem:42D6-S3P0-00SH-8213-00000-00INVESTORS USE SEMA WINDFALL TO CHASE UP DIDATA AND LOGICA; MARKET REPORT2001-02-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:48ZLexisNexisBUSINESS; Pg. 21INVESTORS USE SEMA WINDFALL TO CHASE UP DIDATA AND LOGICA;
 MARKET REPORTStephen Foley

DIMENSION DATA and Logica shares were chased higher yesterday as fund managers moved to re-invest their windfall from Schlumberger's acquisition of Sema.

Dealers reported heavy turnover in Sema, which has agreed to a 560p-a- share cash bid from the US oil services giant. Beleaguered investors are liquidating their holdings in Sema ahead of the completion of the deal, anxious to end their association with the company, which issued two devastating profit warnings in the space of two months.

In order to keep their desired weightings in the IT services sector, fund managers were yesterday moving the cash into stocks such as Didata, up 16p to 441p, Misys, 12p better at 650p, and Logica, which rose 46p to 1,595p. The process has gathered momentum since Friday's big tech sell- off, which brokers said created a number of bargains in the sector.

There was little cheer elsewhere in the New Economy. The telecoms sector, in particular, suffered another rout, with Vodafone sliding 6.5p to a two-year low of 198p. Investment banks were yesterday warning that regulatory delays mean it will probably now get less than the 11bn euros (pounds 7bn) originally agreed for the sale of its Infostrada business in Italy. Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein told clients: "This obviously provides Enel with the opportunity to renegotiate the price following the fall in telecoms asset valuations since the deal was made."

Nerves went wider than the Italian job, amid the well rehearsed arguments over the gloomy global outlook for telecoms growth in economic slowdown, and after the giant sums paid for third-generation (3G) mobile licences. But dealers took heart that the collapse in valuations - which included another 38p fall, to 1,362p, for Colt Telecom and 19.5p off the Cable & Wireless share price, now 777.5p - was done by lunchtime, when the stocks began to find support. BT, whose chief executive was quoted in the weekend press as admitting to paying pounds 10bn too much for 3G licences, had another yo-yo performance, falling almost 4 per cent before bouncing to close up 10.5p at 610p. Orange also ended up, 4p better at 565p.

The day's moves meant Vodafone has again lost its crown as the UK's biggest company. Last night it was worth pounds 127.8bn, while oil giant BPAmoco was worth pounds 130.4bn. BP shares jumped 13p to 580p after a new spike in the oil price, prompted by the US and British airstrikes against Iraq. Shell was 7.5p better at 589.5p.

The UK's number three company, the drugs goliath GlaxoSmithKline, was up 37p to 1,920p. Tomorrow it reports its first figures since the union of Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham at Christmas. Investors were betting yesterday that it will announce bigger-than-expected savings to be made from the merger. There is also hope for a clearer strategy on research and development when gsk presents to analysts in London on Thursday and New York on Friday. Observers thought the resurgence of interest in gsk prompted a switch out of rival AstraZeneca, which dipped 8p to 2,928p.

Vodafone's problems were cancelled out by the heavyweight gains elsewhere and the FTSE 100 was settled at 6,094, up 5.7 points. With Wall Street closed for a public holiday, and many dealers taking half-term with their kids, trading was light. All the other indices were marginally weaker on the day, with the FTSE techMARK 100 off 14.6 points at 2,505.39 and the FTSE SmallCap down 4.2 at 3,259.3.

Even the FTSE 250 was off 2.4 at 6,716.8, despite the advance of an army of housebuilders. George Wimpey topped the performance table with a 12.5p rise to 177p ahead of interims tomorrow, and Persimmon was 18.5p better at 292p on a strong recommendation from UBS Warburg, the investment bank.

Generics, which advises on the commercialisation of technology, was boosted by an investment note from its house broker, Merrill Lynch. Analysts there highlighted the potential for its current projects to receive third-party funding that would crystallise their value. The stock was up 500p to 29,000p, and at this level it will be challenging for a place in the widely-tracked FTSE 350 in the run-up to next month's index reshuffle.

Dicom, the data-capture technology group, was up 12.5p to 560p as investors bet it would release strong interim figures this morning. Haynes Publishing, which publishes motorbike manuals and car-parts catalogues, rose another 2.5p to 130p. It has now made up the ground lost since its profit warning last month, and more. Gossips say it could prove attractive to an opportunistic predator.

SEAQ TRADES: 97,423

SEAQ VOLUME: 1.48bn

s.foley@independent.co.uk

GOSSIPS RECKON things are on the up at Helphire, the motor accident claims management firm, and that it may be about to bag a lucrative marketing tie-up with the AA.

The group lost its battle against insurers who had refused to reimburse the cost of Helphire's repair and replacement car services. But yesterday it agreed a pounds 17.6m share issue at 75p - the stock was unmoved at 76.5p - and a new agreement with the insurance industry.

MARKET MOVERS

Beazer 197.5p (up 7p, 3.7 per cent). In line with Persimmon, its acquirer.

Cape 14.5p (up 2.5p, 20.8 per cent). Dealers believe selling by Equitable Life is coming to an end.

Corus 82.75p (up 4.25p, 5.4 per cent). Consolidation hopes ignited by giant continental merger of Usinor, Arbed and Aceralia.

J Sainsbury 385p (up 12p, 3.2 per cent). TNS market share data shows sales improvement.

KeyStone Solutions 30.5p (up 5p, 19.6 per cent). Positive press comment after fundraising.

National Express 910p (up 18.5p, 2.1 per cent). Late surge on news it has sold Bournemouth and East Midlands airports for pounds 241m.

Psion 192p (up 6p, 3.2 per cent). Siemens agrees to use its Symbian platform for smartphones.

Range Cooker 20p (up 2p, 11.1 per cent). Hopes of a bid from Glynwed.

Scottish & Southern Energy 628p (up 17p, 2.8 per cent). Seen as a potential merger partner for Powergen.

Telecom Plus 117.5p (up 24p, 25.7 per cent). Third quarter figures show company is back in the black.

Tesco 268.5p (up 7.5p, 2.9 per cent). Analysts told it will meet forecasts.

WPP 810p (up 15p, 1.9 per cent). Brokers positive ahead of tomorrow's full-year results.

Automotive Precision 8.5p (down 1.5p, 15.0 per cent). Profit warning blames overseas set-up costs.

Energis 454.5p (down 21.5p, 4.5 per cent). Worst hit as telecoms sector slides across Europe.

Foresight 125p (down 45p, 26.5 per cent). Says 137.6p of net asset value came from the defunct e-district.net, suspended yesterday.

Intec Telecom Systems 374.5p (down 41.5p, 10.0 per cent). Disappointing first quarter earnings.

Sage 315p (down 11p, 3.4 per cent). Acquires TAS for pounds 9.7m cash and debt.

Spirent 428p (down 17p, 3.8 per cent). Market discounts slowdown in telecoms operators' spending on equipment this year.

SSL 409p (down 107p, 20.7 per cent). Profit warning and resignation of chief executive.

Telework 144p (down 12.5p, 8.0 per cent). Splashes out pounds 6.8m on Solus.

urn:contentItem:5Y95-H7J1-JBJ7-N3HW-00000-00Investors wake in fright to Sanders presidency2020-02-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:47ZLexisNexisInvestors wake in fright to Sanders presidencyJacob Greber

Donald Trump wants Democrats to pick Bernie Sanders so he can pillory him as a dangerous radical. But what if America is ready to elect a democratic socialist?

Between the coronavirus, sluggish economic growth, tapped-out monetary policy, deficit-driven economic growth and a president shaking the foundations of the global trading system, it's not like Americans didn't already have enough to worry about.

Now here comes Bernie Sanders, the independent "democratic socialist" whose promises of "political revolution" and a slug to the wealthy to fund healthcare and education for all have turned him into the front-runner among Democrats vying to become president.

While US stock markets have for days and weeks seemingly ignored the big-picture threats from viruses and policy-driven asset bubbles - sending the stock indices to ever-higher records - the spell appears to be broken.

So far this week, the Dow Jones Industrial Average has shed more than 1900 points in two days - or more than 5 per cent - its biggest decline in more than two years.

Analysts believe at least some of the drop was caused by the Vermont senator's big win in Nevada on Saturday, which adds to his first place in the New Hampshire primary earlier this month.

"You have a lot of things that are overhanging on the economy and now you have the introduction of the idea that Bernie Sanders might be the nominee for the Democrats," said Anthony Scaramucci, a Wall Street money manager who once worked as Donald Trump's White House press secretary and has since vowed to campaign against the president in the lead-up to November.

Scaramucci believes the odds of a Sanders victory against US President Donald Trump in November are already at 45 to 48 per cent.

"There has to be a probability that [Trump] doesn't beat him," he told The Australian Financial Review on Monday. "So once Bernie Sanders is named the nominee, you know there has to be a correction [in markets]."

The sudden resurrection of Sanders ahead of more conventional moderate alternatives, like former vice president Joe Biden and former Republican and former New York mayor Michael Bloomberg, is forcing Wall Street to revisit what the independent senator's presidency would mean in practice.

Active in office since 1981, when he became mayor of the New England town of Burlington in Vermont, Sanders has for most of his public career been dismissed as an obscure and slightly laughable left-wing figure, who famously took his wife on a honeymoon in 1988 to the Soviet Union and set up sister-city programs with places like Puerta Cabezas in Nicaragua and Yaroslavl in Russia.

In short, the bearded lady of American politics.

But nobody is dismissing him now. Over the past decade, Sanders - who joined the Senate in 2007 after 16 years in the House of Representatives - has watched and benefited as a large slab of the Democrat base shifted in his direction.

Having narrowly lost the 2016 Democratic nomination to Hillary Clinton in 2016, Sanders relaunched his bid for the presidency early last year and has stood out as the party's most organised and prolific fundraiser ever since.

Ideologically, Sanders says his way of seeing the world is no longer on the fringes and argues that his model for America isn't anything people in Scandinavia or many other parts of Europe would regard as radical.

"Ideas that seemed radical four years ago are now kind of mainstream," he told 60 Minutes' Anderson Cooper on Sunday, the day after his thumping victory in the Nevada caucus.

Grassroots fervour

The speed of that shift is coming as a shock to many on Wall Street, not the least because Sanders is riding a wave of grassroots fervour among mostly young voters who are buying into the senator's plans for an all-out assault on corporate America and its hard-charging model of capitalism.

As president, Sanders would reverse Trump's corporate tax cuts, returning the headline rate back up to its pre-2017 rate of 35 per cent from 21 per cent and lift the federal minimum wage to $US15 ($22.73) per hour.

Consistent with his campaign attacks on the "billionaire class", Sanders wants to introduce an "extreme wealth tax" on top-earning Americans alongside a national "wealth registry" to prevent tax avoidance.

Those with net worth north of $US32 million would pay 1 per cent, rising to a maximum of 8 per cent on wealth above $US$10 billion.

Sanders also wants to halt capital gains breaks for households with incomes above $US250,000 and believes there should be a tax on all Wall Street financial transactions.

Next would likely be what could become the largest trust-busting campaign in a century, targeting for a break-up of "too big to fail" banks and big tech firms that together account for about a quarter of the S&P's market value.

Another Sanders priority would be to shift power away from corporate America towards workers by putting union representatives on boards, strengthen labour rights and force big companies to transfer up to 20 per cent of their equity to workers via so-called Democratic Employee Ownership Funds.

Healthcare plan

And that's just the start of the senator's potentially market-moving platform.

His boldest promise by far would be the creation of a national healthcare scheme that would do away with private insurance that currently covers around 160 million Americans.

In its place would be a universal system that he says would cost less while extending coverage to more than 30 million people currently outside the system and countless others with inadequate coverage.

Sanders' campaign options for funding the healthcare plan include using revenue from his wealth tax as well as the administrative savings from having a single payer replace thousands of insurers, which one estimate puts at about $US600 billion a year.

He has flagged a system in which workers with a family of four earning more than $US29,000 would pay a 4 per cent family premium on every dollar earned above that level. The campaign said on Monday that it would save the average family currently paying private insurance $US4,775 a year.

Employers would shift away from private premiums, which cost on average $US14,561 for a worker with a family of four, to a single 7.5 per cent payroll tax at a cost of $US4500, they said.

Still, introducing "medicare for all" would lift federal spending over the first decade by between $US32 trillion to $US34 trillion, according to calculations released last year by the Urban Institute, a centre-left think-tank in Washington.

That number is greater than the American government's total cost over the same period for social security, medicare and medicaid - the nation's largest entitlement programs - according to Congressional Budget Office projections.

Another major Sanders proposal is to cancel all college debt and make public colleges, universities and trade schools tuition free, which his campaign has costed at $US2.2 trillion over ten years.

Then there are big-spending plans to provide "housing for all" ($US2.5 trillion over a decade) and universal childcare ($US1.5 trillion).

And even if a hostile congress blocks much of the Sanders agenda, Trump's liberal use of executive orders has created a precedent for wide-ranging intervention across the economy.

Sanders has promised to introduce government regulations to curb emissions. He wants to ban fracking and supports shuttering existing nuclear power reactors and slash $US1.22 trillion from defence spending.

While the weekend's Nevada caucus win by Sanders triggered a sharp sell-off across US healthcare and drug stocks, some analysts have argued that his plans could actually spur economic growth, at least for a time.

Plans for removing the burden of repaying university debt and providing a single-payer healthcare system could free up household resources for new spending and investment.

Sanders also backs infrastructure investment and has expressed approval for a "Green New Deal" splurge on high-speed rail, electric transport and more public options to cut emissions.

"Wall Street's getting nervous, the insurance industry's getting nervous, drug companies are getting nervous, and the Democratic establishment is getting nervous," Sanders reportedly told supporters in recent days.

Scaramucci suggests the Sanders resurgence is linked to deteriorating income inequality caused by the same interest rate cuts Trump has so vociferously demanded of the US Federal Reserve.

"The great irony of the interest rate activity and the co-ordination of the Federal Reserve with the global banks is that it's having a very big effect on populism, the spectre of nationalism and all this other stuff," he told The Australian Financial Review.

"The rich have gotten way richer. "

The result is a pending battle between a "radical, oligarchic right-wing figure in Donald Trump, that's going to be going up against a first-time self-declared American socialist."

"I would tell you right now: don't underestimate the passion and the angry disaffected people who feel disadvantaged by the elites and the establishment that could potentially side with a guy like Bernie Sanders," Scaramucci said.

So far, Trump appears to relish the idea of a Sanders nomination, applauding the senator's Nevada win and urging him to fight against the Democratic Party machine's desire to install a moderate.

Clearly, it's because many Republicans believe Sanders will be an easy beat once they've pilloried him as a dangerous socialist radical desperate to impose a Venezuelan hell-scape on the American people.

While there's every chance that strategy will work for Trump come November, there's a risk for the president that just enough Americans in the key swing states might go for the Sanders plan, assuming he gets the nomination.

Sanders is no Jeremy Corbyn, the failed British Labour leader whose plan included genuine socialism such as the nationalisation of railways, electricity distribution, the post office, and water utilities.

But he still seems radical by conventional American standards. If that's still a thing.
